item.title: The colorful world of Chris Miller
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12082" align="aligncenter" width="579"] OG Combi - FS Boneless[/caption] Chris Miller. What would it be like to be him? Can you imagine? A world flooded with color. Perfect fluidity. Natural. Imagine standing on a skateboard and knowing that you are style personified. Some people got it... I received these images from Grant Brittain. They are a wonderful example of skateboarding and one of its greatest riders. All life is color. Thanks to Grant for the images. Thanks to Chris Miller for beng exactly who he is. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12083" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Baldy frontal[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: True skating style personified . .
Reblogged this on Gøηє ツ Ska†îηg and commented: A Living Legend...

Chris Miller was relevant nearly 30 years ago in the skateboard world. Fast forward nearly 30 years, Chris Miller is ONLY relevant in the skateboard world. A very small world, indeed. Great skateboarder, arrogant attitude. No thanks.

item.title: Christian Hosoi - there and back again.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12093" align="aligncenter" width="325"] Christian Hosoi- Marina[/caption] Ripping it with style... Christian Hosoi. I think that the first time I ever saw a photograph of him was in Action Now magazine. I recall it being an ollie in the brown bowl at Marina. He just continued to get better and better. Nobody was as exciting to watch on a skateboard as Christian. He was bigger than life. The world fell at his feet. He embraced fame. He gained everything, lost himself, then lost it all. Now... Christian is a great example of how one person can fall by the wayside but overcome it all and return to a wonderfully healthy place. He serves as an inspiration. Style. Perseverance. Legend. Thanks to Grant Brittain for the rocket image. Skate - Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12092" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian Hosoi- rocket[/caption]

item.title: Father / Daughter
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12099" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arto Saari and his daughter Ella[/caption] "Today is the 4th of July. Another June has gone by... but when they light up the town I just think what a waste of gunpowder and sky." - Aimee Mann Jonathan Spooner and I drove to Hollywood today. We stopped and grabbed some food for a BBQ. We met up with Wesley at Arto's.  It was gorgeous outside. Arto was puttering around with chores and such things. "It's better doing projects than living in the projects." We laughed. Arto took his two year old daughter - Ella - around the deep end. She kept saying, "Pool. Pool. Pool." It made me smile a whole bunch.  I still can't skate but the crew held it down. There was something super cool about Arto and his daughter just playing together in the pool. I envy him. Children are a gift... Aimee Mann's lyrics were inappropriate for this holiday.  Today was beautiful for so many reasons. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12100" align="aligncenter" width="584"] awesome![/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Rad dad
When I read him this article and showed him the pics, my 4 year old told me we had to drain his uncle's pool! He's got his mind working on recon and draining ops already!

item.title: Jonathan Spooner
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12111" align="aligncenter" width="701"] Jonathan Spooner - FS Smith deathbox. Image: Arto Saari[/caption] Jonathan Spooner once worked for me at the Mission Valley Skate Park in San Diego. We rode a slew of pools, drank too much caffeine, listened to a great deal of speed metal, set up booby traps to keep people from breaking into the park, rode the Vans vert ramp three times a week... and on and on. You get the picture? We are brothers. We've been hanging out quite often lately. I rather enjoy his company. Yesterday we hit up Arto's for the 4th of July. Spooner threw down some super fast Smith grinds over the box and Arto captured this moment in time for us all. Stellar! Thanks to Jonathan for being a good friend and thanks to Arto for the image. Skate... and be good to your friends. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: hey oz its bryan from mission valley park, just wanted to say hello and thank you for all the good times we had at the park. to this day my greatest skateboarding achievement was being able to skate the baldi full pipe and pool riding with you and the rest of the crew. i will always have the most respect for you and what you did for me, thanks man.

item.title: El Coyote - another look
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: El Coyote Salba Jake Reuter Adam 12 The lady Toby Burger In a certain area of the 'Badlands', there is a small neighborhood / community that is quite unlike anything else I've seen. The majority of homes are little more than hovels; rundown, threadbare, patched up, cinder block & shingle boxes. Poverty & its ever-present shadow--despair--are everywhere. Rusting fences criss-cross the yards & keep the dogs at bay. It seems that everyone has a pit bull. It seems that all of those pit bulls are very very angry. I am glad the fences are there. Dilapidated cars are ubiquitous & trash is heaped at every glance. Its hard to believe that a 'god' exists in such a place as this. I think that most of the people living here are 'illegals'. One can see the face of fear at every turn. Salba found this pool from an airplane around 2004. I think the people were 'anti' when he checked it out & they turned him away. He bided his time. He is a master at 'recon' & the art of the 'long game'. He can wait decades....and has! Recently, fate turned her face our way & we welcomed her sweet glance. The little lady was empty...& abandoned. In the hot winds of July, we went there. We swept off her blistered surface & cleaned her face. She shone. We rode & all was well. Chaos & abandon. All the cards were held in the right hands. Then, she was gone. A new tenant. A new fence. Padlocks. Large angry dogs seething with hostility. El Coyote was great while she was ours. Thanks to Peter King, Brandon Wong, & MRZ for the images. Skate-Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12130" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Peter King[/caption]

item.title: Cleveland
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12133" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Scott Ward[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12134" align="aligncenter" width="584"] bucket brigader[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12135" align="aligncenter" width="584"] rain rain rain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12136" align="aligncenter" width="584"] rainbow? now wait a minute...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12142" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Adam 12[/caption] Cleveland. Here today, gone tomorrow. She was small but round. She was fast and fun... but she wouldn't last. We found the Cleveland pool in the fall of 2008. By spring, the pool was a dirt lot with weeds. I was absolutely surprised when I showed up one day. Pool gone. House painted. Dirt lot. It is just the way it goes. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12141" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cleveland[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12137" align="aligncenter" width="584"] bumming[/caption] Cleveland pool walk

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That was a super good pool.

The people that live there may walk over the same spot Ozzie is standing in the last photo but they will never have any clue or understanding of the monumental efforts and deeds committed there. Skaters are the explorers . . not the settlers.
Start digging!

item.title: these old folks are pretty cool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12145" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Z-Boys at Hall of Fame Induction[/caption] Jim Muir, Jeff Ho, C.R. Stecyk III, Peggy Oki, TA, Jayboy... there were a whole bunch of badasses in that hallway when this impromptu image was taken. Old folks. Decades of ripping. Most of them barely knew what was happening at the time they did what they did. They just did it. That doing changed so much for so many. I stood to one side and didn't speak. I watched. I know and have met most of the Z-Boys team by now. It didn't matter. Seeing them altogether was like a high voltage fence you couldn't touch. It was safe to stay across the room and watch.... I watched the wrinkles on their faces. I noted the easy friendship and warmth. Bygones. History. I was content to be breathing the same air as these fine people. People that defined who I am. I looked over at my best friend Jim Howell and said, "These old folks are pretty cool!" We just laughed... Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Well Spoken..... True Greatness.

item.title: Guest Post - Wesley Trbovich
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12148" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rune Glifberg[/caption] Wesley Trbovich I woke up this morning to another beautiful sunny day in Southern California. After cranking out my morning routine, I headed up to Arto’s for a little warm up session. When I got there, Rune and Corbin where already in the deep end sweeping out the infamous death berries. The charging commenced and the smell of burning metal filled the morning air. After the wake up session, the plan was to go meet up with Lance in the SGV and head to Rusty’s for a few hours. Plans quickly changed and we moved the session to Angelo’s for some action at The Clover. [caption id="attachment_12149" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wesley carving while Corbin , Angelo and Lance look on[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12150" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Angelo- BS grind[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12151" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain reaching...[/caption] Between Lance and Angelo’s ever comedic antics and Rune’s oh so serious blasters, there were some heavily balanced vibes in the air. After a couple hours of ripping and the sun setting itself so beautifully behind the mountain, it was only right to go soak our bones in the Jacuzzi. As the night winded down, I had to stop and think about just how lucky we are. I mean, come on. How many people share a common passion where they can get together with their pals and entertain each other for hours on end doing something they love? When the days get hectic, it is times like this that remind me how truly blessed we all are. [caption id="attachment_12152" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wesley, Trevor, Rune, Arto and Lance[/caption] Thank you to Arto Saari for the images. Big shout out to The OZ man for allowing me to be a guest on The Blue Tile. It’s a true honor. Until next time… Wesley Trbovich

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wesley, you rule man! I'm glad I got to meet you and skate with you while I was out in California visiting Ozzie. Stoked on you and your deal! Thanks again Ozzie.

Featuring skateboards and memorabilia from the 1930s to present day. The majority of our exhibits are on loan from Todd Huber's Skatelab - Indoor Skatepark and Skateboarding Hall of Fame Museum.
601 Embarcadero Suite 4 Morro Bay, California 93442
Phone:    805.610.3565
Open seven days a week, 10am - 6pm.
facebook.com/MorroBaySkatelabSkateboardMuseum
[caption id="attachment_12164" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Logan and G&S[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12165" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jack Smith - racer, legend and curator[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: As always if it has something to do with skateboarding Jack Smith must have some involvement in it. Sort of 6 degrees of separation from Jack Smith so to speak-LOL! I have never met Jack face to face however we have spent the past several years emailing each other pictures and stories of this great sport we both love and have fond memories from. You will not find a greater guy than Jack and I can only wish him more great success with his newest adventure. Keep up the good work Jack!! Dennis Allgeier from Bel Air, MD.

Jack, love the set up and vast collection of your Skateboard Museum. I can only imagine the fun an old timer like me would have walking down memory lane. I use to own the entire Cadillac Wheel poster collection you have on the wall behind you. A few years ago I sold them for $200 each to help make the rent . . . have missed them ever since. I will be sure to drop in and see you and the memorabilia when I get to California.
Cheers, Monty
Monty, those posters have been reprinted. If you contact Jack he can let you know how to contact the guy that made the posters.

Hi Jack it all looks great, I talked to Randy today and told him that you would like all 3 or our re-make designs for your museum, so I put a bug in his ear maybe you can follow it up with a e-mail or a call!

item.title: Steve Alba- Spring Valley Hester I
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12169" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Steve Alba at Spring Valley - Hester I practice[/caption] Salba. Hester I. 1978. He won the first pool contest ever. History. Believe it... There have been many pretenders to the throne but he has the trophy. In the 1970's, skateboarding was different. You had to have consistency, tricks, lines, flow, style and use of the entire pool. There were guys who rode well and tried to blast, but staying on your skateboard was of paramount importance.  Salba stayed on and lived up to his moniker "La Machine". Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the image at Spring Valley. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12170" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Salba's Spring Valley Hester I - First Place trophy[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Awesome shit...... Look at those funky old Rector pads........And looks like he was nursing a bad left thigh..... Awesome....
Salba is so rad. That photo is great. Stoked!
A HUGE inspiration!!!

Great shot of SALBA. I especially get a kick out of the "belt grinder" grip tape. That sure was a short lived fad. Can't count the number of things we tried for better grip. The stuff used to just tear your skin apart if it hit you. It also didn't last very long. The only other stuff more devastating to come in contact with was an Ick Stick deck.

item.title: PK
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12182" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Peter King at Black Powder[/caption] Peter King is a really rad dude. He bought the Ridiculous house where I live. PK grew up in La Jolla and has surfed and skated since he was a grom. The first time I skated with PK, Reuler brought him out to the Badlands on a pool mission. We were skating a pool over in Fontana and everyone was having a bit of difficulty getting to the deathbox. PK pushed in and just sailed right over the thing...! I was thinking "Dang bro!" I like skating with PK and since he is always on the road with Hurley,  we don't go on missions nearly enough. "Hey PK! Get home and come skate!" Love- Ozzie

item.title: Baldy- a look back.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12194" align="aligncenter" width="584"] it is the journey, not the destination...[/caption] Baldy pipe. Years of skateboarding madness has echoed through its hallowed corridor of concrete beauty. Pioneers. Muck, Tay Hunt, Autry, Valdez, Schneider, Cortum, Ayers, the Alba brothers, Hawks, Worm, Biniak and the list goes on and on. Through the 1970's and up into the modern era, skateboarders all over the world have made the holy pilgrimage. It is THEE place one must skate! [caption id="attachment_12195" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Michael Serna Jr. - "One giant step..."[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12196" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Samwise Gamgee - up in the Baldy hole[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12198" align="aligncenter" width="584"] one must heed the writing on the wall...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12201" align="aligncenter" width="446"] Andy Macdonald - image: Grant Brittain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12202" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Serna Skate Clan Birthday Session[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Reblogged this on Gøηє ツ Ska†îηg and commented: Great article guys. I was just their in June thanks to Randy Katen and Micke Alba, still sick as ever!

Great article my friend. I was just there in June thanks to Randy Katen and Micke Alba. Still sick as ever after all these years. Keep the goods coming I love re-posting your work. Peace!
Rich Monday

Thanks Ozzie for this great post on Baldy. I'll never forget the day that Worm took us to L-Pool and for a late afternoon heavy session with his buddies from Ick Stick. These were complete unknown flat wall rippers. To watch these guys float the flat wall on both sides of the mouth of the pipe was the magic of The Badlands skaters. Their ability to understand and push skating into the unknown of the then present vert knowledge was a sight to behold. Don't even get me started on how awesome Worm was. Greatest skaters I ever saw. Truly a humbling experience. GH

item.title: William Sharp Book Project update
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12205" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay Smith at Mondo's pool. San Fernando Valley... through the viewfinder[/caption] I left San Diego at 4:00 am this morning. I had to get above LA traffic before I was sitting on the freeway. William Sharp lives in Oxnard. It was a long haul. We went through color slides today, splitting them into manageable categories. Contests, parks, pipes, pools, banks, ramps and lifestyle. I saw Scott Foss and Stevie Cab images when they first were put on the Bones Brigade. There were shots of Strople, Brad Bowman, Shreddi, Bela Horvath, Tony Alva, the Alba's, Kona Boys, Gunnar, DP sans tattoos, Bulky Olson completely destroying, Hackett looking like a million dollars....  you get the idea? There are countless images of Winchester, Big-O, Hester I and Hester II, Marina / Gyro Dogbowl contest and numerous images from other contests. I looked at insane images until I thought my head would explode. Bill smiled and handed me a clear sleeve full of slides and I put the viewfinder up to my eye.  One of the enduring pool images of all time: Jay Smith fully lapped over on the hip at Mondo's pool! So unreal. We worked until we couldn't any longer. I am beyond stoked. This is 'dreams come true' stuff going on here...  Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12207" align="aligncenter" width="460"] William Sharp[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Sheeze...look at that shot of Jay..one wheel on the deck and one wheel on the wall. Absolutely a very powerful move for its time. Pushing the boundaries of commitment. Jay always stoked the SD Boyz. One of a kind front-side lapover . We called it a Smithereen.
Can't wait for the book
That shot of Jay is as good as it gets . . pure.

thank you for covering the uncovering of the single greatest skate shot in history...the jay smith lapover! i have always talked about that photo as the quintessential shot, and felt that Mr Sharp never got the respect he was due (compared to the other marquee names at the time). needless to say, i will be waiting impatiently to pre-order my book the minute i hear about its availability. and if he ever chooses to sell limited edition prints of that Smith photo, i'm cracking open the piggy bank!
Ozzie, you know how I feel about Jay Smith, How both of us feel about Jay Smith! This lap over photo is just proof of his insane grace, power and STYLE!

item.title: Baby Blue Tile
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12218" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wesley, Mason and friend.[/caption] Wesley Trbovich A Skate is a charity organization for children with autism. On Wednesday, June 27th, I had the amazing opportunity to hang out at Arto’s house for a BBQ and pool session with A Skate’s founder Crys Worley and some other volunteers for the organization. Mason, a soon to be ripper, watched in awe from the deck. He had never stepped on a skateboard before and he swore he never would. “No way,” he kept saying. “It’s too scary!” I was able to get him to sit in the shallow end and watch the action from there. He summoned up enough courage to allow me to push him up and down the transition while he sat on the board. He soon graduated and reluctantly agreed to try a few runs standing up. [caption id="attachment_12220" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Fallon Worley[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12221" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Sasha Worley[/caption] After the first go around, his fear was quickly replaced with an overwhelming excitement. “Again, again, again,” was all he could say. The magical look on these childrens faces brought back the feeling that I felt the first time that I got on a skateboard. The freedom. The innocence. Their glows quickly became contagious. I wish that I could somehow bottle up this moment and keep it for later. [caption id="attachment_12225" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Alex Salillas[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12226" align="aligncenter" width="421"] Jason Salillas[/caption] As long as we never lose sight of why we started skating in the first place, we’ll always have our own little fountain of youth. I would like to thank Crys Worley for all the time and effort that she puts into helping children with autism and for creating such a wonderful organization. [caption id="attachment_12227" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Crys Worley, Emma and Arto's daughter Ella[/caption] Thank you to Arto Saari, Jeff Fribourg and Joel Ahren for the stellar images. Thanks- Wesley Trbovich [caption id="attachment_12228" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wesley, Sam and Mason[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Grounded. That's what they feel. "Mom, for the first time in my life, I found a sport that being tense helps" ............ these words were said by my teenage son with asperger's (mild autism). My son is a long boarder who craves speed....maybe, just maybe he will be known to you. thx for all you do!
brilliant post

Great post as always! A skate is doing some fantastic work. My son has aspergers and I never dreamed he would skate. He fell off once and it was always no! No! No! After that. Then at 11 we were at vans in orlando (rip) and out of the blue he's like I want to do that! Two years later he is tearing it up and I am so jealous of his gorgeous frontside turns on the wall in pools. So keep it up A skate and tell bones to make those wheels in SPF 58mm so we can support them!
yall should have a skate camp for girls

item.title: Angelo's 50th
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12241" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Angelo with the ruckus just getting started.[/caption] Angelo had his 50th birthday party. It was to be a non-skating type of evening. Music, good food and dancing. Most of the guests were not skateboarders so...  As the day dwindled and the guests began arriving en masse, Angelo, Pat Ngoho, Brandon, Tyler, Trevor, Chris, Wesley, Tony Alva and a few others decided to do a quick run through the pool. Bill Sharp was on hand and grabbed his camera to document. [caption id="attachment_12244" align="aligncenter" width="584"] TA[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12246" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Pat Ngoho - always makes the cut[/caption] I herded a few folks over to the pool... One well dressed gentleman asked me, "How are skateboards ridden in a pool? What about the water?" I gently took him by the elbow and escorted his wife and him through the archway leading to the pool. His eyes became larger as he saw the clover pool come into view. His questions ceased and he became silent. Truth in all its naked glory. Trevor put one over the hip about chest high. The man smiled. At last, he understood. [caption id="attachment_12248" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Trevorrrrrrrrr[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12249" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chris- up on top[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12245" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brandon- lien to tail under a watchful eye[/caption] There was a terror train running in the clover as Alva, Angelo and the boys quickly followed each other in a long line to speed through the pool. People were stoked and although they didn't know what stoke even was...  they felt it. That was the important part. When someone finally feels stoke, they realize what's missing in their own lives. These people watched and I think they understood. [caption id="attachment_12251" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tyler rocked more than this boardslide at Angelo's party...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12252" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tyler, TA, Brandon and me[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12253" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Angelo and the musical entertainment[/caption] Angelo turned fifty. He doesn't act or look like it. That is a good thing. I watched the revelry  that night. Libations. The dance floor was packed. The music pulsed up into the darkness. Everyone was having a great time. As for Angelo,  he had more fun than anyone. Thanks for the party, the fun and a thank you to everyone that came out to celebrate. Thanks to Bill Sharp for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12254" align="aligncenter" width="584"] burn baby burn[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Happy Birthday Angelo . . man i wish I coulda been there.
Happy birthday Angelo! Here's to another 50! Wish I could've been there!
The Shot of TA is great !! Happy Birthday Angelo and thanks Ozzie for another great Story

item.title: these are things we can't ignore
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12266" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bruno Passos - front lip transfer[/caption] Bruno Passos. He currently has more skill and style than most people develop in a lifetime. He's thrown down some pretty remarkable things in the backyard sessions I've been on with him. We had this pool called the Colossus. A massive Roman end. Salba found it years ago. 1990's. It was a monster. Bruno came out and front lipped from facewall to sidewall. It was a pool riding lesson by a master. He was like a magician. Bruno floated. Illusion. I sit here in the half light of my room at Ridiculous. It was a long day. I drove quite a bit and traffic was its usual uplifting experience. Humanity. The streets of Los Angeles thronged with those that have and most that have not. Discrepancies. A filthy man bumped into me and asked me for money. A leper leering at the gate. Reeking of something terrible, he mumbled through splintered black teeth and disappeared into the colorful crowd.  I shrugged. I didn't need the five dollars anyway. On arriving at Ridiculous, I watered my plants, ate veggies and showered. Band Of Horses plays on my Ipod. I am weary. I peer up at this image of Bruno and am grateful that I was there that day. I am happy to know him. For that brief moment, Bruno made the world a better place. This is something I can't ignore. In our disintegrating world, look for good...  then pass it on. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Your blog is part of the good for me everyday. Thank you for doing what you do, Ozzie!

item.title: pumping
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I was draining a pool awhile back. The neighbor lady and her teenage daughters were over and watching me. The mom was looking at all the hoses and --in all seriousness- stated - "With your equipment, you must be good at pumping." I stood silent, digesting what she'd said. I set aside my wounded ego because I realized that this was the first time in my life that a woman has said such a thing to me. Marvelous.

item.title: Vicki Vickers
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: "Women who seek to be equal with men lack ambition." - Timothy Leary Vicki Vickers. Super stylish maven of female vertical riding through the 1970's. Vicki ripped and was certainly not afraid to voice her opinion. In the above article, Vicki drops the hammer on the minimal coverage that women received and the lack of respect among the riders at the time. Women received long looks and little else. I see the same thing going on today. Vicki was ahead of her time. Thanks to Jim Goodrich for the Vickers portrait. Skate and respect the ladies. - Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12295" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Vicki Vickers. Image: Goodrich[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Reblogged this on Gøηє ツ Ska†îηg and commented: Vicki Rules!
She was the image of a hot exotic Californian chick when I was 17.
i wonder what she was doing since then! (perhaps still skating? ;) )

item.title: Lasekland
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12308" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christiano, Miller, Paul Luc, Jimmy, PLG, Daniel and Spooner[/caption] "The crest and crowning of all good... is brotherhood." - Markham Today was a day like any other. Dark coffee, sunshine, warm weather, friends and skateboarding. It is life, how it should be. I phoned Bucky and he told me that I could stop by and bring my friend Daniel Cuervo. PLG and Spooner wanted to ride as well and we phoned Christiano to even out the session a bit. We arrived at Bucky's as he was doing chores and such things. He bid us a good session and meandered down the hill with a daughter in tow. Daniel quickly warmed to the big transitions and flow that Bucky's bowl can bring. Others arrived. Jimmy Wilkins and Paul-Luc Ronchetti walked up to the bowl smiling. They were quickly followed by Zach Miller. Things became really interesting, really fast. [caption id="attachment_12309" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Daniel Cuervo- slob tailbone[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12311" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Pierre Luc Gagnon - Method[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12312" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christiano- lien air[/caption] The crew quickly lit a fuse and a great deal of ripping was going on. Each rider fed off one another's energy.  Everyone is super friendly and all of them share a mutual respect with each other. Camaraderie. Brotherhood. It is a strange religion that we share. The vertical world. A life of pain, fearlessness, barriers of our own making...  it is something that cannot be explained away. Why do we do this to ourselves? Is it worth it? I know of nobody that rides vert regularly for any length of time that could give it up without serious reservation and soul searching. [caption id="attachment_12315" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jimmy Wilkins - Indy[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12316" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Zach Miller - crooked cop[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12317" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Paul-Luc Ronchetti- Method[/caption] I know that when I am riding or simply hanging out with these guys, I feel a bond that transcends ethnicity, race, ideology...  we are a brotherhood. We ride pools, bowls and vert. We do this to the exclusion of almost everything else. I personally wouldn't change a thing. Thanks to Bucky for the session. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great post, great Pics, very good worde, I could not have said it any better. Chris
Great post. We are indeed a brotherhood.

item.title: David Hackett at Pipeline
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I think it was in 1977 when we heard about the new Upland Skatepark featuring the first Man-Made Pipe Built for Skateboarding. I had already been out to Ride the big (illegal) 24 Foot Ameron Desert Pipes in Arizona with Alva, Biniak, Valdez, Shogo and Kent Senatore, so we couldn't wait to ride a "Permission Pipe"!
I think this was our second trip to Upland, because on the first one, they didn't have the Aluminum "L" Brackets you see on either side of the Fluorescent lighting in this photo- On the first trip Jay Adams came off a high backside slash and lost control, shooting his Z-Flex at about 100MPH straight into the Lights and caused a Fluorescent dust and Glass shower in the pipe that was INSANE! - No Skating that night in the Pipe!
In this photo, I was on my last days riding for G&S due to my association with the
DogTown crew, and I was starting to hang and ride allot with Tony, Jay and Wentzle. The board in this photo is actually a deck TA rode, then gave to me- A solid oak Alva Proto-Type he dubbed the "Model T". Since I was still under contract with G&S, I put G&S stickers on it, Bennett trucks with those two tone (yellow & red) YoYo Pro wheels- which were actually pretty fast in those days.
I'm sure glad this photo is in B&W because I couldn't stand the Yellow & Gold G&S colors we had to wear...The ONLY reason I could bear it was that Stacy Peralta and fellow DogTowner Paul Constantineau were also on the team, so I figured it was cool...After this session I started to Ride for Alva Skates.
Funny that we wore this silly little Volleyball knee and elbow pads- The were worthless and the knee slide had not been invented yet.
On this day, it was me, Alva, Adams, Biniak and I think Shogo- we set the Bar pretty high that day- The cement in the Pipe was still curing, so our wheel marks were ingrained into the upper regions of 10 and 11 O'Clock for the all the Locals to see and take notes...it would be months before anyone else Blazed the same lines and the Upland Pipe was never the same....

item.title: David Paul / Kona Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12327" align="aligncenter" width="584"] David Paul. Acid Drop. Kona Bowl.[/caption] DAVID PAUL Looking back at the Kona Bowl, I  would just like to state that the Kona story is much bigger than one man can tell. This is solely from my perspective. Back in the early 1970's,  I lived in Pacific Beach in San Diego. I surfed and skated with my bro's down there. We would skate hills, driveways, schoolyards that had banks, and pools. At the schools, they had benches. After watching skaters like Ty Page jump off benches or jump over cars, I started to do it too. Back then, I was starting to enter contests and met the north county boys- Murray Estes, Gunnar and many others. We had our own pools in Pacific Beach at the time and were really starting to love them. So, when I met the north county crew, they told me of the Kona Bowl!  It did not take long before we visited it. We went as many times as we could and carving, kick turns and flying off the shallow end stairs were the norm for me. I think this all started in 1974-75. [caption id="attachment_12329" align="aligncenter" width="584"] shallow end destruction... Kona Bowl[/caption] After seeing skaters jumping off benches,  I tried it at Kona one day. I just rode right in and made it! I jumped into the shallow end about three and a half feet or so to the flat bottom. At the time, I was riding a  Bruce Logan model with X caliber trucks with Road Rider 2's.  I would break my trucks all the time!  At that time and as far as I know, no one could do the acid drop at Kona or anywhere else that I heard about. In the photo, I had joined the Tracker Trucks family and was not breaking trucks as much. I also started skating for Sunset surfboards and skateboards. Thanks to Murray Estes, shown in the photograph with me. The board in the image was a Murray Estes Sunset model.The wheels were UFO's. Last but not least, my trucks were Tracker Half Tracks. Thanks to Lance Smith for the images. - Dave Paul [caption id="attachment_12331" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tracker Trucks advertisement[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Sheeze....David Paul taking flight off the Kona Bowl deck. I will never forget the first time David launched one of his airs skyward and just slapped his board onto the floor of Kona. Who said acid drop? This was like an acid air. Then he proceeded to carve the right flat wall and then push into the heart of the bowl and throw an insane backside tail tap air. One of the best goofy-foot skaters to understand and manage air time. Thanks Ozzie for a trip back in time for us at the Kona Bowl. Respect
David, I have pictures of you skating at the original Kona Bowl with Bobby Means. Didn't you go over the barbwire at the San Diego Zoo to skate? Part of the same tribe, dude. I was there. Don

item.title: Brian Fick
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12340" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brian Fick - Hurricane Combi Corner Image: Borden[/caption] I met Brian through my friend Jonathan Spooner. I was director of the Mission Valley YMCA skatepark back in 1999-2000. Jonathan worked there with me. Brian Fick moved into San Diego about the same time that I left the YMCA. He started frequenting the YMCA and riding with Jonathan and the crew. Our friends were all the same but our paths didn't cross for a long time. One day, Brian calls me out of the blue and asks about bringing Alex Perelson and John Torchia out to ride Ridiculous. They came out and we've become pretty good friends. He is always funny, helpful and -- unlike many skateboard photographers-- he can rip!  He carries the respect of our sports top riders because he can truly take great photographs and he rides along side them daily. Brian is the real deal and I have his back. 100% . He is having a photographic show coming up. Get there. To see more of his amazing work, visit the website link below. His images are stunning. Skate- Ozzie Brian Fick Photography

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hell yeah! Fick rips! Nice to see him on the other side of the lens.

I completed going through all the slides and separating them into groupings. Parks, pipes, pools etc. Now it's on to choosing some Black and White images from over three hundred B&W proofsheets…Oye"  - Bill Sharp

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Damn, you have gotten through some serious skateboard history there Bill! Keep going, we want to see them enlarged and in print.

item.title: an Arizona moment
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Winter 1999, on a North American solo van trip after a hasty divorce, I found myself in Phoenix in a housing project full of foreclosed houses. I was also in the company of some heavy-hitters, armed with skateboards, Tecate, and not much else. A quick hop of a fence, and a foot-sweep of some stones from the dry hole, and the session was on.This particular pool had coping the size of an adult's thigh. Randy Colvin handled it with pure aggression, and control. I re-injured a familiar fracture in my left wrist, so I took a few shots. After about twenty minutes, we split, so as to not bring down the heat. Pool rituals, timeless, and unspoken. Cheers! -  Greg Baller

item.title: David Hackett - "...tell us about it."
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
David Hackett "I think it was in 1977, when we heard about the new Upland Skatepark featuring the first full pipe built for skateboarding. I had already been out to ride the big twenty four foot Ameron desert pipes in Arizona. They were a heavy bust. I went with Alva, Biniak, Valdez, Shogo and Kent Senatore, so we couldn't wait to ride a permission pipe!"
"I think this was actually our second trip to Upland, because on the first one, they didn't have the aluminum "L" brackets you see on either side of the fluorescent lighting in this photograph. On the first trip, Jay Adams came off a high backside slash and lost control, shooting his Z-Flex board at about 100MPH,  straight into the lights and caused a fluorescent dust and glass shower in the pipe that was INSANE! - That ended the skating in the pipe for the rest of the night."
"In this photo, I was in my last days riding for G&S due to my association with the
Dogtown crew, and I was starting to hang and ride often with Tony, Jay and Wentzle. The board in this photo is actually a deck TA rode, then gave to me. It was a solid oak Alva proto-type that he dubbed the "Model T". Since I was still under contract with G&S, I put their stickers on it. I rode Bennett trucks with those two-tone (yellow & red) YoYo Pro wheels- which were actually pretty fast in those days."
"I'm sure glad this photo is in B&W because I couldn't stand the yellow & gold G&S colors we had to wear...The ONLY reason I could bear it was that Stacy Peralta and fellow Dogtowner Paul Constantineau were also on the team, so I figured it was cool...After this session I started to ride for Alva Skates. I think it is funny that we wore these silly little volleyball knee and elbow pads. They were worthless and the knee slide had not been invented yet."
"On this day, it was me, Alva, Adams, Biniak and I think Shogo- we set the bar pretty high that day. The cement in the pipe was still curing so our wheel marks were ingrained into the upper regions of 10 and 11 o'clock for the all the locals to see and take notes... it would be months before anyone else blazed the same lines and the Upland pipe was never the same."  - David Hackett

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Man ! Now that's a story that needs to be preserved for posterity. Such an epic moment in vert skating's formative days. Great write Dave !
awesome!
I think Dave forgot about the lines Worm set there before the D.T. crew showed up there!
Great style Dave,Still keeping it up after all these years!!What A skater!! DPS

item.title: Rennie's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12380" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tristan Rennie lights up Kevin's backyard pool[/caption] Tristan, Nathan, Bill and Sherry Rennie went north for a Canadian journey to visit our good pal Kevin and his wife. They blasted weaponry in the woods of Chertsey, fished in the Saint Lawrence seaway, ate a bunch of great food and skated all over. [caption id="attachment_12381" align="aligncenter" width="427"] Kevin, Nathan and Bill on the right side of a long bang stick[/caption] Kevin met the Rennie's on a visit from Canada back in 2006 and he has been returning to California to stay and ride with everyone ever since. He thought he would return the Rennie's hospitality and there we are. It is how it is done... Thanks to Kevin Caan for the words and images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12384" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tristan- garage bowl Pear Camp[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yeah Kevin!! International skater pals rule!
Very cool but UFO Lit the pool on fire first!!There's still something to say about the inventors!!
what a great time we had , can't wait til next time

item.title: Volcom Bergfest
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_12391" align="aligncenter" width="533"] Jurgen Horrwarth BS Air 1st Place Pro[/caption]

Some of the best skateboarders from Australia, the United States and Europe could be found skating this past weekend at the legendary  Monster Bowl in Münster, Germany at the fourth Volcom Bergfest. The enthusiastic crowd was just as international as the riders who delivered a high level of skateboarding and created a breathtaking atmosphere together with the crowd.. People from Sweden, Holland, Austria, Italy, Belgium and France celebrated a huge skateboard party. The concert by the punk rock veterans from  California, 'The Adolescents', was the cherry on the cake for this contest at the Berg Fidel skate park.

[caption id="attachment_12392" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Adolescents[/caption]

For the first time ever the Bergfest contest took place during two days. The qualification runs for the upcoming skaters of tomorrow was already held on Friday. The highlight of the first contest day was the Death Race which is a variation of a slalom race through the bowl landscape. Tricks are not important, the speed counts and for the second time the local skater Christian Krause was able to walk away with the win and 200 dollars in prize money.

[caption id="attachment_12393" align="aligncenter" width="533"] Ben Hatchell front blunt. 2nd Place Pro[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12394" align="aligncenter" width="533"] Ivan Federics- lien to tail. 3rd Place Pro[/caption]

Berlin-based Jürgen Horrwarth was able to grab first place in the professional group with spectacular skateboarding, fast lines, high airs and impressive lip tricks. Just following up in second place was last year's winner, the American skater Ben Hatchell who laid down some incredibly technical tricks at the highest level. The biggest surprise of the Bergfest was the thirteen year old Ivan Federics from Italy who used the entire park in a creative manner and with loads of tricks. He was able to grab third place in front of Renton Millar from Australia. In the Masters group, first place went to the current reigning German bowl champion Thilo Nawrocki. The street skaters also had a lot to see during the weekend and were able to battle it out with some tough tricks for some prize money during the Globe "Battle of the Bergrail“.

[caption id="attachment_12395" align="aligncenter" width="533"] Renton Millar - FS ollie. 4th Place Pro[/caption]

The live webcast was also brand new this year. An entire camera team captured the whole contest in HD-quality making it possible to watch the contest around the world and the footage is available for the next few weeks online. Well-known personalities from the skateboarding scene were on the judging team. The American vert legend  Ben Schroeder was flown in for the contest to support the judges with his experience.

[caption id="attachment_12396" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Podium[/caption]

The Skatepark Bergfidel support group was extremely pleased with over 1,500 spectators at the event, thousands of webcast spectators and an international group of over 100 skaters participating in the contest: a great amount of feedback and a successful event.

  More information: www.bergfest2012.com Webcast - Volcom Bergfest 2012: new.livestream.com/volcomlive/bergfest2012 Results: A-Division/Pros
  1. Jürgen Horrwarth (35), Berlin, Germany
  2. Ben Hatchell (22), Texas, USA
  3. Ivan Federics (13), Caluso, Italy
  4. Renton Millar (37), Melbourne, Australia
  5. Andrea Casasanta (14), Roma, Italy
Masters
  1. Thilo Nawrocki (39),Düsseldorf, Germany
  2. Tobias Springborn (38), Castrop-Rauxel, Germany
  3. Oliver Gordon (32), Kufstein, Austria
  4. Daniel Beck (38), Echzell, Germany
  5. Jörg Caprez-Keller (41), Frankfurt am Main, Germany
Am Division
  1. Fabian Wenzel (18), Münster, Germany
  2. Tim Turudija (19), Münster, Germany
  3. Sebastian Nienhaus (23), Senden, Germany
  4. Patrick Bormann (20), Münster, Germany
  5. Christopher Skubis (25), Hagen, Germany
Kids Division
  1. Lenni Janssen (11), Düsseldorf, Germany
  2. Eric Springborn (13), Castrop-Rauxel, Germany
  3. Leon Rüb (12), Velbert, Germany
  4. Dean Weidmüller (13), Meerbusch, Germany
  5. Jasper (13), Berlin, Germany

item.title: Jerry Valdez at the Coliseum Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12401" align="aligncenter" width="584"] The Jer - frontside grind from deep to shallow[/caption] August 1977. The city baked under the angry glare of the sun. Smog. Pollution. A yellow haze hung in the air like a bad reminder: "Don't breathe too deeply." Cars jostled for position on the freeways and the streets were crowded as always. Concrete. Humanity. A frantic paced world of chrome, glass and sweat. Jerry Valdez and Kent Senatore cut down an offramp from the 110 freeway. They slipped the car into traffic and moved into the sun driving up Exposition Boulevard. The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum squatted on the left side of them like a giant statue to the gods. Its sprawling parking lots were empty and the team pennants and banners hung lifeless in the hot summer air. Jerry lit another joint and inhaled deeply. Ted Nugent wailed away on the stereo as he handed the smoking weed to Kent. They were headed to the Coliseum Bowl. The neighborhood had changed in the ensuing years since the city had built the Coliseum. Poverty reigned now. Houses sat vacant. Liquor stores flourished and drug dealers peddled their vice to an ever-hungry population. Escape. Despair. They both knew that there were awesome pools to be found in the ghetto's of Los Angeles. They drove around and found them. They kept it positive and real. Kent laughed as Jerry made faces and yelled out of the car at a few teenage girls walking nearby. They pulled up to the pool. Kent helped get the brooms and buckets out of the car. The house sat boarded up. Life had left this place a long time ago. Jerry and Kent pulled old furniture and a bathroom sink out of the deep end. It was a beautiful square pool and the mid wall transitions looked perfect. A few local kids cruised by and watched. Once Jerry and Kent started riding, the local kids grew excited. This is what skateboarding is all about! Jerry pulled frontside grinds as a few local thugs came to the pool. They tried to intimidate but Jerry wasn't having it. They kept riding and the drug slingers left them to their pool. This one lasted for a short while only to be replaced by others. Shelf life then no life. Bulldozers reduced the property to rubble. This image and Jerry's memories are most of what remains. It seems that it is all we'll ever need. Thank you to Jerry Valdez for the memories and Bill Sharp for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Bad Ass panty grams grinder on what appears to be mid-tracks!
Great article & epic pic once again Ozzie & Bill! Made me wanna spark one up as I read it! Hahaha!!

item.title: TA
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12413" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva[/caption] “It is better to be hated for what you are than to be loved for what you are not.” - Andre Gide At one time, Tony Alva was one of the most loved and hated skateboarders on the planet. People loved his success, brash style and intense pool riding abilities. He pushed the frontier of a brave new world. Others hated him for virtually all the same reasons. However, he is still here and most of them are not. There are no pretenders to his throne. He is the real deal. Thanks to Bill Sharp for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: FLUID style light years ahead of EVERYBODY!!!

How can you hate Tony Alva? Truly one of the greatest skaters to walk the planet. His backside edgers were precise and graceful and according to Murray Estes , Tony was badass in the water. Cheers Tony.. you were loved here..no matter what you read in print.

item.title: Logan Earth Ski line unveiled.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12418" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva goes back to Revere and his roots on the Logan Earth Ski Torger model.[/caption] Saturday. I stopped in Hollywood and met up with TA, Wesley and Arto. We had things to do. TA grew up skating at the Paul Revere schoolyard banks and it was where we were headed. Aerial Action Sports is releasing the Logan Earth Ski line this coming Sunday. The Logan family has been involved since the beginning and Bruce, Brian, Brad and Robin Logan are really excited about the upcoming release. Back in the 1970's, the Logan name was synonymous with radical skateboarding and quality products. Aerial has reproduced the Bruce Logan, Torger Johnson and the slalom models. I gave one of the Torger completes to Tony and asked if  I could get a few photographs of him. "Revere" was all he said. I smiled. I knew exactly what he meant. [caption id="attachment_12421" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Revere[/caption] After meeting together in Hollywood, we drove over to Revere. It is a mythical place. A long wire fence wrapped the place tight and within the fences, the descending black ribbon of banked asphalt looked inviting. It cried out... "Come and ride." TA walked up tight along the fence line. We followed. He kept up a running dialogue on past missions, sessions and dodging authority. We smiled. At one end, we pushed on a chained gate and slipped inside between the wires. [caption id="attachment_12422" align="aligncenter" width="584"] stories and memories[/caption] TA quickly flowed like water through the place. Berts, high-speed drifters and cut backs proved that he'd been here before. We took a few photographs and were soon gone into the afternoon sun. The schoolyard fell silent once again. The trees looked on. Quiet sentinels to a stylish start and an enduring classic spot. This Sunday at noon, we will gather in Vista and the Logan family will be there to sign posters and visit with old friends. We ask that you come by and see us. Thank you to TA and thank you to Arto Saari for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: 12:00 noon Sunday

good to see revere is still in effect. brings back good memories of all the westside school banks, revere, belaggio, kenter, pp, venice...

item.title: wasteland
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12435" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Salba rides a remnant of the 2003 fires.[/caption] Fires ravaged the Highland and San Bernardino areas back in October of 2003. The Angeles National Forest lay blackened and charred. Homes were gutted and families lives destroyed. Ash fell onto the streets as far as Costa Mesa in Orange County. It was like a scene from Schindler's List. I watched in morbid fascination as fire crews battled around the clock...  for naught. Within a month, we were moving through the area and taking an inventory. We helped where we could. We were cleaning up the pools. Some of the people didn't care. Some did. Some never returned and never knew. We would drive into the wasteland and return exhausted, dirty, sweat-soaked and content. In a perverse way, we made good on another's misery. We didn't want it that way... it just happened. Lightening strikes. Things burn. Ashes remain. Wasteland. In the month of October in 2003, God looked the other way... Thanks to George McClellan and MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: never
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Never. I have no house, nor will I. Alone I am and will remain. I sit and read. I write poetry and long stories as the candles dance and cold silhouettes writhe across my walls. They are companions that neither argue or love. In the evening, as the sun burns away and lends  itself to the other side, I wander the streets restless. In huge unchewed bites, I devour the sidewalks. A solitary figure, I am hunched over and mumbling. Sometimes I feel as though I understand nothing in my life. Instead, I write lies until I produce a fake one. I invent love. Her. Comforted... I hold it close. She murmurs in my ear, "I will never need another..." I gulp one last breath. Drowning. I have come to realize that there is no lifeguard on duty. If my problem is Russian Roulette, the solution can't be to play less often... the solution must be to throw the gun away. My heart sticks in my chest. I pull and pull... Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wise words Bro...
:) point taken Jeffrey
Enjoy the freedom you have. Things could be worse. If you had three kids and a mortgage you wouldn't have the luxury of introspection.

item.title: some days...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12467" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Zach Miller amid the IG paparazzi[/caption] Some days are a thing of perfection. They don't really go as planned, they are never what you expect and everyone has more fun than should be allowed by law. A few weeks ago, I spent a day with Zach and Chris Miller. We are a doing a 'Day in the life...' type of thing for the Blue Tile Obsession. Arto, Wesley, Lance, Buddy and Rick joined us all and we ate, skated and threw down. We had a really fun day and in the end, the Instagram thing sort-of got out of hand. We were all lined up trying to do an Instagram blowout... I think we accomplished our goal. Some days... Thanks to Arto for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12468" align="aligncenter" width="584"] IG[/caption]

item.title: Converse Coastal Carnage
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12491" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tom Remillard- 2011 Destroyer and Champ[/caption] Converse did it again. The SpeerCo crew came in and changed the Coastal Carnage  ramp complex and added difficulty and lines to an already insane venue. There are more lines than Disneyland and it'll be standing room only as the riders fly and  go head to head for some destruction. [caption id="attachment_12488" align="aligncenter" width="584"] 2012 Coastal Carnage Complex[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12489" align="aligncenter" width="584"] oh yeah![/caption] SpeerCo moved the shark bite peninsula over next to the cradle and added a smaller shallow end with pool coping to one of the bowl hits. All in all, it looks like a complex from the minds of madness. As I write, Al Brunelle, Skreech, Tom Remillard, Lance Mountain, Evan Mock, Curren Caples, Robbie Russo, Riley Stevens and others are taking the thing apart. It'll be insane! Thanks to Converse, Steve Luther and SpeerCo for doing a ripping job. A-Game! Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12487" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Josh Borden lighting up last years shark bite peninsula[/caption]

item.title: Converse CC Day II
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12496" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain hucking one into the hole[/caption] We are soon heading over to the Converse Coastal Carnage. Practice. Day II. Scantly clad females are everywhere. Girls with magic marker invitations written on their stomachs - "Free Hugs." "Take Me Home." "My name is Summer and I'm Hot." I can only imagine the pride that their parents must feel. I laughed quite often yesterday. [caption id="attachment_12497" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Hurley's Peter King. Stepped over from the US Open to surf style a bit.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12498" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lifeblood's Mason Merlino[/caption] The Hurley US Open of surfing is going on as well. The event is literally a beach version of Woodstock. There are parties, cool people, surfing, skating, bands, food and about as much buffoonery as one could imagine. Police are in full force so you better watch your ass. The skate practice has been unreal. My pal Al Brunelle is ripping. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_12502" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al - Heelamonster on the shizzle stump[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Love your commentary on the girls and the messages written on their bodies. Funny how boys never do that at girls skating events (-:

item.title: Kent Senatore - "... tell us about it."
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12509" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kent- Skyline Bowl[/caption] Kent Senatore "That's the Skyline Bowl. It was off Mulholland between Laurel and Coldwater Canyon. The Skyline was walking distance from my dads house. Another spot -- the Toilet Bowl -- was closer and better, but it was crowded with older dudes so we gravitated to this place. When we started skating it, there were only a few of us and some dude that lived in the house directly above it. He rode a 10 speed bicycle in there. He ruled the place at first with those big old wheels and those speed lines of his... The guy would light it up with shop lights on extension cords running from his parents house. It's also the place that I first met Jerry Valdez. The Jer just showed up one day with Mark Smith and Dave Ferry and then did a handstand down the road to the bottom. It had those deep rough grooves for traction. I remember thinking that " ...this dude is fucking nuts!"  I didn't believe a thing he told me for months. By the time this photo was taken, we were way more into the pools, but still rode the school yards and ditches all the time. It was  a cross over period. That is my brother Scott in the background. I don't remember this day specifically, but I do recall when my knees flexed like that without feeling like over stretched rubber bands!" - Kent Senatore Thank you to Kent Senatore for the memories and William Sharp for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Ozzie, do you know if the Toilet Bowl was located on Wrightwood Lane right down the Hill from the Skyline Bowl? Those classic Cali concrete retention basins with those upright corrugated pipes (don't know how they work) always intrigued me for some reason. Even going back to 75 and seeing the first Skateboarder mag with Gregg Weaver on the cover which featured the Toilet Bowl. Guess because we never had anything remotely as cool as that here in Hawaii. Does anyone know where the "Superbowl" and "Viper/Lake" Bowl were located? The Hills above LA are filled with those concrete reservoirs, some unskateable, some aged, some pristine.
Super Bowl is in Benedict Canyon

item.title: CCC - faces to the sun
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_12514" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Omar Hassan- sharkbait to fakie[/caption]

Thursday. The sun burned hot. Why shouldn't it? It cared little for the comings and goings of humanity. It raged in space, a molten thing. One couldn't get close. It let no one in. It was a thing of death... and life. Without the sun, the world would be bleak and cold. There would be no Converse. There would be no contests, no skating, no love. Just survival. Yesterday I saw quite a bit of survival going on at the CCC ramp complex. The heavy hitters were on the deck en masse and things became pretty dicey. Robbie Russo, Al Partanen, Al Brunelle, Curren Caples, Kevin Kowalski, Omar Hassan and others were under the hot sun and turning up the heat regardless.

[caption id="attachment_12521" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Curren Caples - lien melon[/caption][caption id="attachment_12522" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Robbie Russo - cradle crail[/caption]

The riders were working through the differences in the ramp structure, obstacle placement, lines, tricks and jitters. The grandstands surrounding the bowl were filled with beach goers, families and young ladies in bikinis. It was difficult for most not to look up and become distracted. I saw a few things go down. Omar Hassan pulled fastplants to fakie on the shark tower.  Ben Hatchell pulled blunt to fakie on the cradle. Al Brunelle  did a FS Feeble through the cradle and everyone was on their A-Game.

[caption id="attachment_12525" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Partanen- Gosh![/caption][caption id="attachment_12526" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tom Remillard hit Brian Schaffer's leg... and just kept going. Not a care in the world.[/caption]

Today will be another day of absurdity, mayhem and first rate fun. I'll be there on the deck along with everyone else. We'll have our faces to the sun. Thanks to Arto Saari for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Im a caption genius!!
sick coverage, thanks
Omar to Fakie is pure stoke.
who took all the photos? looks cool as hell.

item.title: Lucia
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
June 6, 2012. The afternoon was waning. The sun was beginning to turn the horizon orange as a group of surfers and myself took a boat from the Island of Tavarua, Fiji out across the water to an outer reef thirty minutes away. The light had turned to a late afternoon haze and the reflections were hitting the sea floor perfectly. The ocean waters around Fiji are some of the clearest in the world. They are delightful to photograph in. I was on a location shoot for the World Tour of Surfing as the surf reports had predicted there was to be a huge swell on its way. We were expecting waves nearly twenty feet in height. Big wave surfers from as far as Brazil, Chili and Hawaii had traveled to catch this swell, arriving the day before the massive waves were expected to hit. This photograph was taken on this day as we anticipated the waves to come. I wanted to shoot some underwater photographs before seas became turned up and less transparent. Stu Johnson, an avid and highly talented surfer was surfing around me. The photo was taken of him duck diving his board underneath the blue waves as they washed over him. Being underwater and swimming beneath the waves is a truly breathtaking experience. The colors are magical. The coral and reef are so alive. Vibrant. Brightly colored fish of varying species dart and swim away at our intrusion into their magical world. The ocean holds a strange feeling of latent power. It has a primitive cruelty to it that I feel deep in my bones. Beauty and savagery. One in the same. The giant surf tumbles above in a hurry all its own. No clocks. No feelings. No remorse. It rolls above as I bounce and bump on the rough sea floor. It is truly an adrenaline rush and I couldn’t imagine wanting to be anywhere else. As soon as I arrived in Fiji, I found myself drawn to the sea. It wasn't long before I was in the surf, swimming and shooting photographs. Serenity. Peace.
I realized that I wanted to show the differing perspective from below. So few people ever experience the beauty of what a surfer sees under the ocean waves. There is a primal symbiotic relationship between them both. The wave. The surfer. It can take quite a bit of time to link up and connect a shot like this. To photograph in such an unpredictable environment as one is swimming through the waves isn’t always easy. It can be difficult to line everything up. Stu was great to shoot as he has such a wonderful style. I am pleased that I took this shot because the very next day, I managed to drown my 5D canon body and other equipment. I was shooting off the back of the jet ski and it tipped me off. Horrified about losing all this equipment, I had to come to a realization that such things can happen when working with the ocean and huge waves! It is all in a day’s work. The end result was worth it. When I entered this photo, it was a spontaneous moment where I said, “I have this beautiful, moving image. It inspires me and might inspire others as well. If you can see with my eyes.... ” I entered it with no expectations and now I am utterly thrilled with the response. I feel so fulfilled that --not only does National Geographic like this shot but -- the people that may never have the chance to experience the ocean can see this view. The entire experience is humbling. Gratitude.

item.title: Lucia II
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I have been photographing professionally for around five years now. I am based in California but I travel, often working within the surfing industry and for commercial and other editorial clients. I work as a freelance photographer with my main income derived from the surf industry and my other commercial clients. My mother is English and father Italian. I spent my youth growing up in both Britain and Italy. When I started to surf and travel, I became interested in photography and taught myself over the years. I always worked to make myself better. Different perspectives. Angles and light. It has brought me to where I am today. I come from a family of artists and was raised with music and sports. I have always had an interest in capturing moments with my camera along the way. My first travels were to Morocco, New Zealand and Australia. Purchasing a car, I traveled and wandered through these countries. I trained my eye and educated myself about the world. I never held down a “normal job” and having photography enabled me to be free and do what I love. Having passion for what I do, I built up a rewarding career. It is one I would not trade. I love to travel and see new places and surfing has taken me to some of the most amazing and unique corners of the world. It is hard to say where my favorite places are, especially after spending nearly a decade on the road. Exploring every experience has been unique. I do love Africa, for its wildlife, Sri Lanka for its people and strength, the Pacific ocean for its clarity and California for its diversity. It would be difficult o choose one over another. As far as photographs are concerned, I like block color and I don’t like to alter an image. I like defined lines, parameters, loud and clean. I see color and strength and this is the only theory that makes sense to me. I trust my eye and learn backwards with how I did it. I have learned a great deal in this fashion but I know that there is much to discover. I'm excited to continue my journey and see what I stumble upon next. I love shooting people and working out my photographs. Eyes often always reflect much and everyone has a story. All are interesting to someone. I love portraits, lifestyle, underwater or anything that connects the viewer with another aspect of the world. The hidden. The unseen. All life.

item.title: Lucia III
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I am going back to Sri lanka to document the leopard in its natural environment, I have some surfing commitments in Europe, but I would very much like to push my surf related expertise into a more mainstream avenue and redirect to more travel-related work for a different client base. My fascination with seeing the world and exploring new places and people really pushes me forward. It inspires me. Being able to share the results with people who may never experience such things is a motivation as well. Recently, upon my return from Fiji where I took the picture of the surfer, I also worked on a personal project with the islanders of Yanuca and Benga. They are blessed with the powers of healing. I lived with them for a few weeks and documented their daily lives and rituals, visiting church, meals, ceremonies and coexisting with them. I quietly watched their culture unfold. I am currently putting the resulting documentation together and would like to explore different avenues with these portraits. It offers the world a unique look into a culture that has been seemingly left behind. They live lives untouched by modern pursuits. Untainted and pure. An older more remarkable and peaceful time.

item.title: CCC Friday
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12551" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Greyson Fletcher[/caption] Friday was epic over at the CCC. Every heavy that ever was had stopped by to take a rip and a dip. The crowd was into it and some doubles quickly went down with Riley Stevens and Greyson Fletcher providing some speedy amusement for the masses. [caption id="attachment_12553" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Riley Stevens with a backtail while Greyson hovers above.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12555" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain - invert on the sharkbait[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12556" align="aligncenter" width="584"] heavies[/caption] Greyson is a raw nerve ending. He has no problem getting it all out there! He has shocked me so often in the past while skating that If that dude were to fall out of the ceiling while I was eating dinner, I'd just say "Hello" and offer him a plate! He flew yesterday and the differences between him and the others was noticeable. Lance lit it up, Robbie Russo, Omar, Borden and damn near everyone else were getting their lines down. Everyone was on a tear and the CCC contest is going to be unreal! Thanks to Arto Saari for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Epic

item.title: Converse CC Ben Raybourn Triumphs
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12566" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ben Raybourn - cradle crail enroute to Chuck Taylor 20K[/caption] The throwdown at CCC yesterday was pretty unique. Brian Schaefer and the SPOT guys pulled off one hell of an event. The top twelve riders were all heavy threats and with very few exceptions, the final contest order was anyones guess. Ben Raybourn is a really inventive, smooth and stylish ripper. He utilized the bowl like very few others. With the exception of Kevin Kowalski, Ben was the only rider who really dissected the shallow end, its hips and transfer lines from  shallow to shark to cradle. These two riders actually developed lines unseen before this years finals. The sun was crushing everyone all weekend. The stands were packed. There wasn't enough water in the world it seemed. [caption id="attachment_12568" align="aligncenter" width="584"] The masses baking under a brutal summer sun[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12569" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ben Raemers takes a break during finals practice[/caption] In the end, it came down to some ungodly skateboarding. Ben Raybourn must have decided to take the whole cake because he lit the place up with some of the most amazing skating that I saw all weekend. Other standouts were: Kowalski, Raemers, Fletcher and Barros. Lance Mountain rolled hard with the young guns and proved to be a crowd favorite as well. [caption id="attachment_12570" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain- stands one up under scrutiny[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12567" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Curren Caples flew in the finals with smooth style and perfect FS flips[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12571" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Greyson Fletcher- backtail[/caption] [caption id="attachment_12572" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ben Raybourn. A well deserved CCC Cup and some Converse Cash[/caption] Thanks to Stephen Luther and Converse. Thanks to Brian Schaefer & SPOT. Thanks to everyone that came out. Thanks to all the riders who were ripping and congratulations to the finalists. Yeah Ben! Awesome!. Thank you to MRZ and Arto Saari for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Nice work, Ozzie and Mrrrrrrz. Good to see you guys.

item.title: random
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12577" align="aligncenter" width="584"] empty and useful[/caption] Pain and pleasure. People don't usually change, unless there is some pain. I've seen this in my own life. I think it was Tolstoy who wrote that people always think of changing the world but rarely think of changing themselves. Pretty amusing observation. We always think we are right. The world according to.... [caption id="attachment_12578" align="aligncenter" width="584"] rid yourself of all that muck that's getting in your way[/caption] I had a doctor at the Veteran's Hospital once. He told me that my therapy had gone well and there wasn't too much wrong with me... except my thinking. I think I gave him the finger. Random. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Good words to ponder, I think I tell me son this often (in more words) alas, I need to look at myself, even at my age, to set the example. utah friend

item.title: longevity
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_12589" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Angelo, Jay Smith, Lester, Slade, Ferry, Orton, Jay Adams, Gray and Jerry Valdez[/caption] Recently, a crew of heavies got together and rode with Angelo. Rippers. Every single one. The years of pool riding experience on that deck, on that day...  it was pretty incredible. Longevity is a pretty awesome thing. It teaches you about people and life. Hopefully, it makes you a better person. Most of the things that I learned that were worth knowing... I learned after I was 35 years old. Funny how that works. Patience. Kindness. I learned that I am not the center of life's vortex. I learned that all life does not revolve around me...  These guys are a collective. They are an example. Longevity. Brotherhood. Thanks to William Sharp for the image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Rad post

Ozzie, You are absolutely right on learning at a later age. I am 29yrs old, and lived a wild life. Until I got sober I was not able to understand life fully. Today I look at things from a different view. The photo of those men absolutely show a lot of wisdom, triumph, and commitment to skateboarding/life. Your a very great writer, and I believe you are able to paint such a great picture of skateboarding due to your love/passion for it. Thanks a lot! John Bedard

item.title: William Sharp book project updated
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Steve Picciolo in Pacific Palisades. Stacy Peralta at the Corral pool. Jerry Valdez at the Cage Bowl. Brad Bowman at the Fishbowl. Images. Slices of life. An epic time of discovery and hubris. Pioneers. The unknown... it would never be the same. Bill Sharp and I went through pool slides all day. Our arms and eyes hurt after a few hours. We laughed like small children. Giddy. Inspired. The book is taking shape. [caption id="attachment_12598" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jerry Valdez in classic form. rock-n-roll[/caption] I rode on Monday with Jerry Valdez, Jay Smith, George Orton and Angelo. It could not have been more perfect. Jerry threw up rock-n-rolls, George laid into the coping like he was on his first date and Jay Smith tucked it back. Epic days ahead...  Life. Beauty. History and all that comes with it. Interviews for the book have begun. Thanks to Sharpy for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Super stoked! Can't wait for the book release
Pure treasure OZ ! I don't envy having to decide what goes in and what's left out. How about a 1000 page book with every photo ? :)
Great Pic Sharpy! Jerry is still the Classic Duuude, he's always been, here laying down a Nice rock n roll... It was Great to come together Oz. G O
