item.title: Vanko-bowl.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="450"] sam -trying to cope...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4374" align="aligncenter" width="450"] almost...notice broken coping over box. Sam cut a new one![/caption] [caption id="attachment_4370" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Sam- first grinds & a 'threeler'--badass![/caption] [caption id="attachment_4375" align="aligncenter" width="450"] vanko[/caption]
Ozzie- BS air
[caption id="attachment_4367" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Vanko discovery[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4368" align="aligncenter" width="450"] dump[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4369" align="aligncenter" width="450"] scrubba-dub[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4371" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Sam -halfway in the hoopla[/caption] Salba phoned me around the first week of December & told me about this amazing pool he found. He said he had been scoping the property since summer, but squatters lived there, sharing their poverty, crime & viruses with each other. Not so good! He & Billy, had driven by there over the past weekend & checked the pool. "Big trannies, bullnose coping, stick-tested great, looks killer!" Sam & I gathered at 'Ridiculous' the weekend before Christmas. We took a recon of the pool. On arrival, we made contact with a neighbor & kept it on the 'up & up'. That guy was cool. I have an image of 'Hector' the neighbor, out front with me, pushing water down the gutters with a huge broom once we started pumping the pool. We set up the rig & did what we do. Almost all the way through it, Sams pump started bucking like a 15 year old football dork on prom night. I peered over at him &-- acidly-- asked, "Is that thing outta gas?" Quick check & Sams frown confirmed the worst. We had no gas can & we had less than a foot of muck water left. I pulled on a plywood board over a broken window & crept into the house. Urine & feces smells assaulted my nostrils &  trash was everywhere. I peered throughout the gloom. Silence & decay hung over everything. After being sure there were no 'threats' in the house, I went into the garage. I know you wont believe this, but I found a red plastic gas can with a paper towel in the end. It had about two gallons of gas. Sam & I just grinned at the 'skate gods', as they watched over us once again. The coping over the deathbox was broken, so Sam & I took a piece off the loveseat area & marked it with a 'sharpie'. Sam cut it at his garage that night. Perfect fit. We went back & cruised some runs, grinds & lines on the virgin pool. The next day, Salba, Sam, Ray Zimmerman, Josh Borden, Billy & Adam 12, went back & unleashed a serious barrage on its plaster walls. The neighbors on the other side of the broken property, weren't as cool as 'Hector'. They were 'dope-slinging' hustlers...I think. Regardless of their affinity  for selling crack rocks & their unlawful misappropriation of anothers property, these scumbags put the brakes on our activities. Someday, the boot will fall on them, I'm sure. Realtors fixed up the dump & painted the pool. Its 'shut'. We killed it while it lasted...and thats all that is important. Thanks to Samwise & MRZ for the images. Skate & create. -Bluetile Ozzie

item.title: Don't you?
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_13935" align="aligncenter" width="584"] first light on the 215 south[/caption] Don't you ever feel the need to close the door to life behind you, switch off your cell phone, climb in your car and drive? When relationships become madness and selfishness and ego consume those around you, isn't the freedom of the freeway an awesome attraction? No flight plan. No direction. Forward and backward. One in the same. Jonathan Spooner and I decided to leave San Diego last week and drive towards the desert. We vaguely knew that we would look for some pools and we vaguely knew we would not be taking the asphalt roads the entire time. His Ford Raptor is a pretty amazing vehicle. We literally drove anywhere we wanted. On the way, we met up with some off road pals as well. [caption id="attachment_13936" align="aligncenter" width="584"] the language of steel is spoken here[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13937" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jonathan near Salton Sea[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13940" align="aligncenter" width="584"] desert pit[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13938" align="aligncenter" width="584"] looking forward to looking back[/caption] We made our way to the other side of the Salton Sea. We hadn't been on asphalt roads in three hours. We were driving and passing random places that had to be seen to be believed. Apocalyptic. The decline of all things... Rubble and meth. Squatters. Tents and motorcycles. Crime in the veins. Hard eyes watched our passing. We found pools and desolation. We were driving along and I yelled, "Stop now!" Jonathan skidded to a halt as I leapt out of the Raptor. He backed up to find me squatting over a bomb. Peering about cautiously, I saw others and realized that we had wandered onto a live firing range... marvelous! [caption id="attachment_13942" align="aligncenter" width="584"] rubble[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13943" align="aligncenter" width="584"] yeah, I know.... and this was a smaller one.[/caption] We picked our way out of the place and shortly afterwards, we saw a vehicle shimmering on the horizon. It was the first vehicle that we had seen in a few hours and it was approaching pretty quickly. It turned out to be Border Patrol. He waved us to a stop. "What are you guys doing out here?" Jonathan simply answered "Driving off road." He looked over at his radio and then asked, "Do you know that you are on a firing range? Did you see the jets?" Jonathan and I shook our heads in the negative and then told him that there were no signs or fences. He smiled and said, "Out here...  people just know. Uhmm...  I wouldn't go back up that road if I were you..." He waved us away after telling us that our truck had tripped his sensors and he had come out to see what was going on. Close call. Relief. [caption id="attachment_13944" align="aligncenter" width="584"] pretty much[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13954" align="aligncenter" width="584"] madness or devotion?[/caption] Further down the road, there was a giant mountain made of hay bales and paint. It was a monument to Christ. It was uniquely odd...  it squatted on the desolate, forbidden land like Mecca. Old cars and buses sat on the ground. The tires were long flattened and cracked. 'God Is Love' proclaimed the glaring crimson paint....   and so he is! Jonathan and I wandered the place in silence and awe. Strange. We drove a bit further and saw the Salton Sea to our west. Shoreline. We found some pools. We stopped at a dessicated tree that stood alone on a dusty, cracked plateau. We heard crunching underfoot and realized that we were walking on the bones of countless fish that lay sun-bleached in the dust. It seems that the lakes waters had receded and left the fish to the deadly kiss of the desert sun. [caption id="attachment_13955" align="aligncenter" width="584"] like a fish out of water[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13947" align="aligncenter" width="584"] the curving spine of a fish bakes in the desert sun[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13950" align="aligncenter" width="584"] near Salton Sea[/caption] The sun started dropping and we headed west. The road stretched out in front of us and the Raptor angrily tore at it in huge bites. The rumbling of the engine soothed us. Sunset. Bleeding sky. We stopped in Julian and ate, then made it back to San Diego in pitch blackness. We had turned our back on the world for the day and it was cathartic. Nothing can make me appreciate life like driving randomly onto a firing range. The road less traveled. Dust. Bones and bombs. God is love. Life. - Ozzie [caption id="attachment_13960" align="aligncenter" width="584"] homeward bound[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Where is that pool near the salton sea?
Did you skate the pool at salvation mt
Epic post, loved to read it! Thanks Ozzie. Chris
Great story. So glad you guys are ok. A rad day indeed.
amazing story brother, thank you
God is love/ love is God... Say a prayer 4 Austin Peralta & his father.... Bless their souls.

item.title: I need the sound of rain...
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_13968" align="aligncenter" width="584"] TA- Legendary[/caption] Summer into fall. Heat. There is no shade on the sun. I need the sound of rain... We go to Malibu. An ocean breeze does its best to cool things down a bit. Todd Glaser came along to take some photographs of Tony Alva. It was to be a fun session. Angelo, Mike Early, Olivia Castro, Jimmy Wilkins, TA and I were anxious to ride. Fun was on the agenda. [caption id="attachment_13969" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Angelo- rolling[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13971" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Olivia Castro[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13970" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jimmy Wilkins- double quick 5-0[/caption] The afternoon sun never let up and neither did we. Lines were in abundance and more than a little style was evident. TA charged hard, Jimmy Wilkins lit it up, Mike Early pulled airs in every bowl and Angelo went faster than most everyone. It was good. [caption id="attachment_13972" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mike Early- frontside air[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13973" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jimmy Wilkins- backside disaster[/caption] The sun dropped slowly. The heat remained. It was a long hot summer. I squinted ino the glare. I thought to myself once again...  I need the sound of rain. Thanks to Todd Glaser for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Elvis revisited
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was the first story I ever wrote for my original blog. These events occurred & the next night-- as I was looking through the images that photographer Zach Petschek sent to me-- I knew it had to be told. I only had a Facebook page at the time & couldn't really do anything there, so my friend -- Mich-- set up a Wordpress blog. This is the resulting story. Only about 50 people ever really saw it, so I repost it here. Zach pulled the images for me & here you go. Reviewing it made me laugh. It really was an incredibly odd day. In the photographs of the pool, you can see that the decks are still wet...yet the pool was dry. Strange. I think that Jeff Phillips was looking out over us & smiling.... - Ozzie Zach Petschek village idiot Friday, Zach & I experienced a Twilight Zone  moment & ran with it. As you’ll see, sometimes a person ‘gotta get in, to get out’….ride the strangeness through to the other side– so to speak. I know this sounds vague but here’s what happened. Salba has been telling me about the ‘Elvis’ pool for 15 years or so. “…one of the best pools out there, dude.”  Salba dropped this pearl of wisdom conspiritorially. His story has it that after the Northridge quake of 94, a hundred pools opened up in the valley. Salba, Zask, Tyco, Rhino, Pstone, Reuler and the rest of the heavy- hitters, along with Swope & Royak, killed all of those pools on a regular basis. The ‘Elvis’ stood out among the best. Major obstacles were to be found in its white-plastered environs; like two love seats opposing one another, two sets of side stairs in the deep end and fire-cracker coping. These obstacles, along with big transitions & a very peculiar shape, made the “Elvis’ a task for any good pool rat. The ‘Elvis’ was a permission pool for a short while then quickly found itself relegated to the status of ‘legend’….the one pool you should’ve seen & rode but probably would never get the chance. Elvis Elvis opposing A few weeks ago, the grapevine sent out the word that the ‘Elvis’ was empty again. Friday, I had the day to myself. I contacted Zach & left San Diego at 6:00 am  for the long drive up. It was bleak, overcast & grey that morning. The sky was like dull metal and we rode quietly north listening to Katatonia & thought of ‘Elvis’. About halfway into the drive, I sent out a text to Big Al Glasco (who was meeting us ) that we were enroute. I received his reply. “Its raining hard”. I groaned & pulled over. I phoned him.  "Wet.  Too wet”,  Big Al stated tersely. Damn! Zach & I agreed to stop & get some coffee and here’s where things went loopy. I pulled off the I-5 at the next exit and stopped at a Starbucks. As we got out of the car, we saw a diner on the opposite corner called….GULP! -- OZZIE’S DINER. We were dumbfounded…but it gets even stranger. I had to go check it out! We go inside for coffee & I see a huge neon sign 'Ozzie’s' on the backwall over a booth. It has photographs of Elvis Presley underneath!! We were like….WTF! Todays Special: New Pool Elvis & I We then decided that the skate gods wanted us to continue to the ‘ Elvis pool” regardless, and this we did. It was pouring rain but we traveled on & an hour later pulled up beside the place. By then, the rain had stopped but all the streets were wet. We decided to -at least- take pictures of the pool anyway. The sprawling house was heavily overgrown with ivy & vines, and  huge Roman columns upheld the vast roof. The large white front gates had wrought iron images of music notes, guitars, and the moniker “Melody Land” on its face. We stealthed our way inside & found the pools surface …DRY! I know! I know! But it really was dry! We swept it  & skated it hard for 45 minutes before a  heavy rain shower put itself down & put us out of the sesssion. Bruce Lees’ son-- Brandon-- had a quote that’s perfect for this little (true) tale…”It doesn’t have to rain everyday.” Thanks to Zach Petschek for the images. Skate-Ozzie Elvis-Land Zach- loveseat ride in the drizzle

item.title: Elvis -Revisited
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was the first story I ever wrote for my original blog. These events occurred and the next night-- as I was looking through the images that photographer Zach Petschek sent to me-- I knew it had to be told. I only had a Facebook page at the time and couldn't really do anything there, so my friend -- Mich-- set up a Wordpress blog. This is the resulting story. [caption id="attachment_13986" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Elvis[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13987" align="aligncenter" width="584"] "... in the cold Kentucky rain."[/caption] A few weeks ago, the grapevine sent out the word that the Elvis was empty again. I pulled off the I-5 at the next exit and stopped at a Starbucks. As we got out of the car, we saw a diner on the opposite corner called….GULP! -- OZZIE’S DINER. We were dumbfounded…but it gets even stranger. I had to go check it out! We go inside for coffee and I see a huge neon sign 'Ozzie’s' on the backwall over a booth. It has photographs of Elvis Presley underneath!! We were like….WTF! [caption id="attachment_13991" align="aligncenter" width="584"] weird... Ozzie's Diner AND Elvis photographs.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_13994" align="aligncenter" width="584"] front gates to Melody Land[/caption] We then decided that the skate gods wanted us to continue to the Elvis pool regardless of the rain, and this we did. It was pouring rain but we traveled on and an hour later pulled up beside the place. By then, the rain had stopped but all the streets were wet. We decided to -at least- take pictures of the pool anyway. The sprawling house was heavily overgrown with ivy and vines, and  huge Roman columns upheld the vast roof. The large white front gates had wrought iron images of music notes, guitars, and the moniker “Melody Land” on its face. We stealthed our way inside and found the pools surface …DRY! I know! I know! But it really was dry! We swept it  and skated it hard for forty-five minutes before a  heavy rain shower put itself down and put us out of the sesssion. Bruce Lees’ son-- Brandon-- had a quote that’s perfect for this little (true) tale…”It doesn’t have to rain everyday.” Thanks to Zach Petschek for the images. Skate-Ozzie [caption id="attachment_13993" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Zach Petschek- loveseat in the drizzle[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Such a great story.
This is a great story, and more so because it actually happened in just that way. Thanks for posting, makes me want to take a trip and discover.
And it shows up as empty on google maps.

item.title: end
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_13999" align="aligncenter" width="486"] standing watch[/caption] La fin du monde. Perhaps the end of the world happens for people in differing ways. For some, it may be the death of a family member. All the shared memories and dreams become a terrible reminder of the loss. Tragedy. Woe. Perhaps it is catastrophe. Apres moi le deluge. The flood. Plague and pestilence. On September 11, 2001, all the world seemed to burn and everything was strangely chaotic and lopsided. It seemed as though everything we knew had fallen down and landed on its head. Sometimes, the world breaks for good reason. Ripperside Shawn and I find life in shambles frequently. We saw a family home today. An old woman had lived there. Church bulletins were scattered about. Denture cream and Depends boxes lay in heaps of trash. She must have been handicapped. I could see evidence of her long occupation of the home. [caption id="attachment_14000" align="aligncenter" width="486"] handicapped[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14001" align="aligncenter" width="584"] seen some better times...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14002" align="aligncenter" width="336"] her life in rain[/caption] From the floor, I picked up a curled, yellowing black and white photograph. A tired-looking elderly woman, stared back at me. Her eyes could not hide the weight of her existence. I placed the photograph up on a window ledge so she could see the trees outside. Faded knick-knacks and memorabilia sat in dusty niches reflecting the dirty sun that filtered through the broken windows. It seemed cold in the house. Colder than it should be. Ghosts. I felt lost... saddened. It was like part of her still remained in the detritus of her broken life. The pool lay out back in an overgrown lot amid a tangle of tree limbs and refuse. It had obviously been unused for decades. It must have been an obscene daily reminder of a happier time. Cookouts, swimming, family. [caption id="attachment_14005" align="aligncenter" width="584"] disuse[/caption] Tires and garbage were strewn about. I saw  broken glass. Others had come this way after she left. They always do. Vermin. They scurry in the night and pass on their virus and disease. The dark teems with a thousand horrors. We walked through, saying very little. Her story was there. On the floor and in the rubble. The end of her world. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_14006" align="aligncenter" width="584"] witnesses[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Masterful writing my friend . . you truly have a gift Ozzie.

Every single time I read your stories they make me wake. Between your keyboard and camera you akways show us life in such way that make us think. Thanks for sharing with us...life. my back hurts once in awhile but I wont quit skating.

Great write up, Oz. Abandoned homes have a way of expressing our utter impermanence as few other things can. Look up photos of Gary, Indiana. Or Detroit. Tough times for folks and a lot of life's work and hopes left to rot. I'll forever have the image of a black and white photo facing outward in a window sill. A small, yet incredibly meaningful act of dignity and respect in a place that had none.
Check out my new F.B. page Scotty'sSkateboardSecretSpot!

item.title: Stop-n-Go
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_13568" align="aligncenter" width="500"] Mike Coco- lien air over the deathbox. Circa- 1983[/caption] Origins Stop-n-Go pool. Riverside. It was found in the late 1970's or early 1980. The local Ripperside crew emptied it out and proceeded to tear it apart at every opportunity. Mike Coco was one of these and Tim Trudell was another. Rippers! The pool was a swimmer for many years but there would be little sessions from time to time. Over the decades, it was watched over like a treasured family keepsake. Others would ride its smooth round walls and lady-finger coping. [caption id="attachment_13572" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Riverside Ed[/caption] In recent years, Riverside Ed worked at getting the pool going as a permission. It had transferred ownership numerous times. Ed told me that he and Kevin were driving around one day & saw the slide. It was around 1983. They saw that it was an empty house so they drained and skated it then and there. They told Tim Trudell and Mike Coco about it shortly after. These four guys had the pool to themselves for quite some time. The Stop-n-Go pool was named after a local mini mart nearby. Stealth. Secrecy. You might find the Stop-n-Go mart and buy a couple bags of Skittles and a Coca Cola, but you weren't going to find the pool! Over the years, it was lost to them. It became a swimmer. New owners. Families. They kept sharp eyes on it. Drive by. Recon. Fast Forward [caption id="attachment_14018" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Stop-N-Go[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14019" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Drehobl (hidden), Hewitt, Stafford, A. Perelson, Fick, Brunelle and Ripperside Shawn[/caption] Recently, Alex Perelson called me. He wanted to skate some backyards and we set up a session day. Stafford, Hewitt and Al came along with Fick. They brought Dan Drehobl who I hadn't seen since Woodward in the early 1990's. It was ultra-hot. Over 100 degrees. We baked. Everyone tried to get something going but the suns glare cut us to the bone. Within an hour, everyone was gasping and the water supplies were gone. We managed to obtain a few photographs and everyone did have a good time. I told the crew the history of the pool and that I had images of Mike Coco ripping it in the early 1980's. Everyone just shook their heads... amazed. The longevity of the place and its history were over shadowed by the pounding the sun had given us. [caption id="attachment_14022" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Peter - shade[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14023" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Alex Perelson- back Smith[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14024" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Josh Stafford- frontside 5-0 light/love[/caption] We rode for a bit longer and everyone tried to rally. Alex drove to a nearby store and grabbed water for everyone. This brought relief and a few more things went down but for the most part, the brutal life draining sun took everything that we had. It was time to end the day. Food. Water. Rest. [caption id="attachment_14027" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Peter Hewitt- rock-n-roll[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14028" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle - frontside 5-0 light/love[/caption] Thanks to the crew for coming out and Riverside Ed for keeping the pool going. Thanks to Ripperside Shawn for the session and thanks to Brian Fick for the images. Thank you to Mike Coco for being so rad! You rule dude... Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: All the images are sick but the Mike Coco pic blows my mind. So rad. Timeless!

item.title: crew
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: Drehoble (hidden), Hewitt, Stafford, A. Perelson, Fick, Brunelle and Ripperside Shawn

item.title: Pamela Brodowski
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I first met Pam back in the summer of 2008. She came out to ride backyard pools with some pool pals. I was stoked to see a girl charging on the backyard plaster. I don't think girls look good black and blue but it was a strange comfort to see a woman tackling the steep backyards that we went to. It was pretty cool. I have seen Pam here and there over the years. She is always smiling, positive and friendly. When I heard of her diagnosis, I was bummed...  I knew that she would be going through some Hell. As a former Oncology RN in a major hospital, I have seen and assisted in the treatment of many people. To combat horror, sometimes you need to use greater horror. Chemo and Radiation can be a MF. I have seen it first hand. I applaud her fight and courage. There is a fundraiser for Pam coming up at Fontana. Please attend and let us help her. Thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ohio Rob sending a few bucks in honor of Blue Tile Obsession. Great blog.
Thank you for the kindness

item.title: William Sharp Book Project - Wally Inouye
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14045" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Wally Inouye[/caption] Tom Wally Inouye If my memory serves me right, this shot was taken in late 1978,  right after I left Sims for Caster. At the time, I was living in San Diego and would make the drive north to skate places like Marina, Lakewood, and Upland. In this shot I'm riding Chris Strople's model, with a flat deck, no concave and a wedge tail. It has Gullwing trucks and Wing wheels with TRW MRC 38ff bearings ($138.00 a set). The Marina Del Rey skatepark-- back keyhole --saw some amazing sessions. For me it was about my equipment. Jumping ship from Sims to Caster was not motivated by money, but by performance.  Bill Caster was a premier surfboard shaper for the Big Rock and Wind-n-Sea crew and truly believed in quality not quantity. He along with Ken Watson (Watson Laminates) brought this quality to skateboards. Casters boards were made from hard rock maple with epoxy resin and two layers of 6oz fiberglass. Not only were they strong but they had a life characteristic to them we called BOING. Gullwing Trucks came from the slalom side of things and Mike Williams first gave me a set to try. While still on Sims, I decided to join the Gullwing team along with Strople, Kubo, Kimbel, Martinez, Piercy and Williams. They developed Wings wheels, which were very fast for their time. Brad Strandlund would always help me with my equipment by taking all my wheels and putting them on his lathe and making them perfectly round. Sometimes, he would cut grooves on the riding surface if I was going to ride plexiglass for added traction. He would lathe me special inside and outside lips or conicals. Brad also turned me on to the best bearing ever. It was the TRW MRC 38ff bearing.  It was an aircraft bearing and you could turn your board upside down and spin your wheel and it would still be spinning for as long as ten minutes!
Other random things from this photograph. Rampage stickers. Rampage were the first halfpipe skate ramp plans done by Tom Stewart. SIO sticker by Barry Zaritsky. SIO were padded skate shorts. Town & Country. Everyone knows Town & Country. The Sharp brother's. I can't say enough about them. They took me to pools in the Valley with Valdez and Senatore. They were great photographers and easy to work with.  Pool riding today blows my mind. What I see these kids doing in backyard pool is totally insane. They are taking it beyond known limits. Pool riding will continue forever. If you want to see it live and you have a pool in your backyard, then CONSERVE WATER - DRAIN YOUR POOL. Once it is empty... skaters will find it.- Wally Inouye
Inouye's Pool Service since 1976
Addendum
This will be the last post on Blue Tile Obsession for the most part. I am putting things on hold while I focus on the massive task at hand. We have thousands of slides to review and scan, pages to layout and interviews and stories to collect. I am trying to finish everything in December so it can be ready for publication in January. I will post an occasional update on Blue Tile Obsession during this time. Thank you for the support. Have a rad holiday. Spend it with someone you care about...  Love- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Such a great photo early marina without the fence seeing Wally killing the upper keyhole .great great photo

Good luck with the project Ozzie, really looking forward to the final product.
All the best

Fantastic post by Wally! He was always one of my favorite skaters, with amazing style. His attention to detail, right down to the bearings and stickers on his board, is wonderful to read.
Now, regarding your Addendum...Say it ain't so! I need my daily dose of BTO! Please TRY to put up a FEW random posts while you finish up the book project! Thanks, and Happy Holidays!
Thanks WaLlY & OZziE, Ditto the above comments. Love hearing the background insider stories. Hope all goes well 4 ya OZ.

I feal like those guys at the end of the movie the truman show, "what do we do now" All I can say is I really hope things go well with the book. Yes I want to see the finished product but really I just need my daily pool fix!
I really enjoyed the Wally post. Good luck on the book! Can't wait to get my hands on a copy.
Love Wally. I copied his IPS sticker in 77 and made my own APS stickers. Good luck with the book Oz and looking forward to it. Have a great Christmas.

item.title: hellhole.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Doug Kinkade- 'style'
[caption id="attachment_4618" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Riverside Sean-FS ladder 'thread the needle'[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4620" align="aligncenter" width="450"] 'the company you keep'[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4621" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Brandon Wong- side stairs-- second pass.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_4622" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Jake- shallow rock-n-roll....proper![/caption] We drove the windy road to the high desert. Gusts of 50mph, buffeted our car & made semi-trucks weave down the freeway like giant metal snakes. Trash billowed by & I saw long black plastic sheeting stuck in a steel guardrail girder; its tattered ends snapping in the wind. Burnt brush from roadside fires were shadowed by the huge propellers from the wind turbine power generators that lined the I-10 freeway. What a desolate hellhole! We drove & met with our pool pal-Doug & his friend Jake. In a 7-11, I saw crystal meth users, chewing, clenching their jaws & scratching the -invisible- bugs off their arms. Nervous & fidgeting, they stood in line to buy cigarettes, eyes bulging & darting. They looked like skeletons. In a dead voice, the one guy asked for Marlboros. His pal stole a handful of candy when the clerk turned away. He looked at me as if to say, "Go ahead & say something." I stared him right in the eye & flinched... not one iota. He looked at his shoes then left. I saw police cars prowling. I smelled overflowing dumpsters. I saw filthy babies  playing in dirty yards. I saw 'Pit Bull' dogs, growling behind broken, graffiti-splashed fences. I saw rusting looted cars. I saw furtive looks & fear. I saw ignorance & poverty everywhere. We drove north & Doug quickly took us deeper into the hot afternoon. We pulled up a side street & stopped. He pointed to the right. I had already seen it. A boarded up shit hole, greeted my roving eyes. We grabbed our gear & hit the fence in the back. A perfect little 'Rossmore' kidney was sitting there. Bullnose coping, perfect shallow transitions & very little cleanout awaited us. A quick sweep & it was 'on'. Kevin Burke, Jake, Brandon Wong, Doug Kinkade, Riverside Sean & I, had so much fun. We laughed & made disparaging remarks about each other, everyone ripped and the day quickly flew by on wings of its own. We left & everyone drove home stoked. Thinking back, I realized that we had visited a place that is overflowing with plague, virus, pathos & pain. Out there, the world is a hell for some people. We took that 'hell' & flipped it on its head. We created wonder out of chaos. Only skateboarders can do that! Thanks to Brandon Wong for the images. Skate-Ozzie

item.title: Cruel Sun
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Many skaters stay away from the desert areas because of the heat. However, I have-- more than-- a few friends that go wherever the pools are. Their thinking is quite the opposite of those that sit by the 'beach cities' & complain. I have pool pals back East that drive several hours & shovel snow in order to ride pools. I guess its simply a matter of being spoiled. Lets face it...California skaters have a 'golden ticket'. Its all here & always has been. Sometimes though, you must earn it! Recently, a great crew from Orange County & the surrounding areas, got together & drove out into the heat of Coachella Valley. They cleaned, swept & prepared the pools, then tore it up. The heat was a secondary consideration & the bullnose coping took a brutal pounding that day. I saw more smiles & progression than I had seen in quite some time. That is really what its all about...isn't it? Skate-Ozzie

item.title: What is in a name?
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_14060" align="aligncenter" width="584"] ztuntz rider- Al Brunelle- front rock[/caption] What's in a name? Some say that a great deal rides on a name. I am not sure that this is always true. The owners of the skateboard manufacturing company that I work for developed ztuntz skateboards. Stunts. Flip it on its head and it still spells out what it is. I like when things are exactly what they are supposed to be. Its a shame people aren't that way. We could really make some damn progress in the world. People deceive, inveigle and obfuscate. However... I digress. [caption id="attachment_14062" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rylan Mancilla[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14067" align="aligncenter" width="584"] David Hackett[/caption] Stunts. ztuntz. I have heard some peculiar skateboard company names. Some made it and some did not. In the end, it really seems to come down to the people. Again... the people. The people are what make things work, promote truth and convey passion... or not. If people are out for themselves, things are bound to fail. The greater good is not in the interest of the self-servers. A company is only as good as its people, its skaters, its product and its heart. At Aerial, we have a good bit of those things. [caption id="attachment_14063" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Daniel Cuervo[/caption] You should know me by now. I am not saying this because they pay me. If I didn't believe in what I am doing, I'd be cutting grass or digging ditches like I was last year. There are no shortage of lawns to cut. But there's a lot of sleepless nights in store for me when I don't keep it real. [caption id="attachment_14065" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Archer Braun[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14066" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jason Thurtle[/caption] These guys make great boards. They have re-issued the Logan Earth Ski line and Dave Hackett's Black Leather Racing and Malibu Surf Skates are good lines to check out. Al Brunelle, Daniel Cuervo, Archer Braun, Rylan Mancilla, Jason Thurtle, Dave Hackett and myself, all ask you to check out the skateboards. Thanks- Ozzie ztuntz skateboards Logan Earth Ski

item.title: Free Former
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Free Former World Championships Skate event program with rider names Dennis Martinez -'Vert Wall' Ellen Berryman Long Beach Arena Stacy Peralta I am posting this tonight, as I won't be able to do so in the morning. I am such a ‘skate history’ dork! Recently, I went to San Diego & was visiting Jim Goodrich. We were going through his old slides & photo-albums. I noticed a few slides from the California Free Former 1977 contest held in Long Beach that year. He also had a ‘program’ & the ‘rider listing format’ in his possession. Just look at the names on that list…amazing! Tony Alva, Bob Mohr, Ty Page, Bruce Logan, Paul Hoffman & Robin Logan, just to name a few. I quickly asked if I could photograph the priceless items & received the ‘go ahead’. Jim told me that the ‘vert wall’ you see in the Dennis Martinez image was gnarly. The contest organizers were giving a hundred bucks to any rider that reached the topmost letters that say ‘professional’. I think they kept their 100 $. People came close…I suppose contests & all have changed. That is a good thing. I love progression. Bruce Lee stated that “Change is the changeless state.” I’m not quite sure what he meant by that, but it sounds cool…and Bruce Lee said it, so it has to be meaningful. Anyway, I know these are not pool images, but they are a super reminder of where we all came from. Thank you to Jim Goodrich for being so gracious with us all. You rule Jim! Skate-Ozzie

item.title: INDIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Jake Reuter, Cam Dowse, MRZ and I. We drove the windy road to the high desert. Gusts buffeted our car and made semi-trucks weave down the freeway like giant metal snakes. Trash billowed by and I saw long black plastic sheeting stuck in a steel guardrail girder. The tattered ends were snapping in the wind. Burnt bushes from a roadside fire were shadowed by the huge propellers from the wind turbine power generators that lined the I-10 freeway. Desolation.  In a store, I saw meth users clenching their jaws and scratching the -invisible- bugs off their arms. Fidgeting, they stood in line to buy cigarettes. They looked like skeletons. In a dead voice, the one guy asked for Marlboros. His pal stole a handful of candy when the clerk turned away. Police cars prowled. I smelled overflowing dumpsters. I saw filthy babies  playing in dirty yards. Savage dogs growled behind broken, graffiti-splashed fences. I saw looted cars. I witnessed furtive looks and fear. Despair was everywhere. We found our way into an old neighborhood. We knocked on doors. Shut down. Doors closed abruptly in our faces. We hopped a fence at a foreclosure. Perfect plaster glittered in the sun. Dust and debris swirled around the drain of the deep end. I swept. We were quiet. Jake and Cam took two runs each. Grinds. Speed. Flow. I heard voices. "Really?  Hey... My baby is asleep!"  I looked over a fence and a neighbor scolded me.  I gave the others a signal and we poured over the fence...  disappeared. [caption id="attachment_14089" align="aligncenter" width="584"] glittering prize[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14090" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jake- first wall before the fall...[/caption]

At an old favorite, we received a welcome smile and the pool opened up to us. The Powell Peralta team was along for the ride. Cam, Jake, MRZ and I put up high fives all around, as Chad Bartie, Deville, Terry, Shane Borland, Josh Hawkins and Steven Reeves stepped into the backyard and started the session.

[caption id="attachment_14082" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Hawkins, Bartie, Reeves, me and Reuter[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14095" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Steven Reeves[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14084" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chad Bartie[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14085" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shane Borland[/caption] The energy level was high. Chad Bartie was just returning from an injury and it was good to see him working out some lines for the first time in awhile. Shane lit it up with crail reverts and Steven pulled Smith grinds. Everyone was ripping. It was rad to see Josh Hawkins in the pool as well. Cam ripped the deathbox and Jake pulled tail taps on the side wall. [caption id="attachment_14086" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cam Dowse[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14087" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jake Reuter[/caption] We headed back towards Ridiculous. I invited everyone in for a nightcap. The invitation was accepted. Lights lit up the darkened backyard. There was still some work to be done and --mark my words--it would get done! Shane Borland was a powerhouse all day. The sun dropping on the horizon didn't detract him from throwing down. Josh flew about the pool in a carefree manner. He spent a fair bit of time with his trucks on the coping. Jake ruled with an iron hand and his blunt slide sealed the deal on the day. In the end, everyone was happy. Skateboarding pools with some friends will always be the mark of a good day. Thanks to the crew and to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_14097" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shane- frontside glide[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14098" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Josh Hawkins- Smith[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14099" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jake- bluntslide[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great skating as usual Ozzie...but what's with all the spray paint junior high stuff. I cannot remember one time when any local skater took a rattle can to Kona,VC Rez,VC pool, Escondido Rez. Me thinks there would be more permission pools if it was not for these latent destroyers of fine concrete and coping. Enroll in art school and leave the walls alone.

Pools in the dirty downtrodden areas of any city are usually covered in graffiti. It isn't usually the skaters doing it. I think it is their version of art/poetry/self-expression. Whether we like it or not, it makes sense to them in some strange way...

we old guys know to leave only grinds, the taggers always blow out our spots. In montreal we hit this and only pool , the motel is boarded up . and now fully tagged. Now they throw us out and give fines if caught on prperty, before all the mess they really did not care. i have no problem dropping a dime on one of them. why dont they target the banks and big buisness the real problem in the world today.

item.title: Sabrina's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14108" align="aligncenter" width="642"] Brad McClain- side ladder[/caption]

Huntington Beach, California. Her name is Sabrina. She'd been in the old house for over nine years. She had been there for so long, she hardly remembered anything else. Time means very little during prosperity, but let life kick everything sideways and it will quickly change the situation. Time becomes an enemy. The long wait for nothing. Watch the sun crawl across the sky. Another night. A lonely dawn. The property had been kept in good repair. The pool surface had been damaged by chemicals though. A few years back, Sabrina had the surface repaired. She spent a great deal of money having a fiberglass shell installed on the pools surface. Then came the downturn. Job loss. Financial strife. A government that neither noticed or cared. The American ream.

[caption id="attachment_14111" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Hawkins, Deville, Bartie, Reeves, McClain, me and Terrry[/caption] The story is familiar. Peanut found the pool one afternoon. Green and black water. He started draining it. He didn't know it, but Sabrina was on her way home and would catch him in the act. Sabrina was unhappy and police intervention was considered. Peanut offered quick financial compensation. In her current situation, it was hardly an offer that Sabrina could refuse. After all, he seemed like a pretty nice guy... They struck a deal and he got back to the job of water removal. The transitions revealed themselves. Stellar. The sessions soon began in earnest. There was one rule: bring your wallet. If you wanted to play, you had to pay. [caption id="attachment_14116" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chad Bartie- Smith over death[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14118" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brad McClain- frontside floater[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14117" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Josh Hawkins- ollie death[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14121" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cam Dowse- front Smith[/caption] Sabrina has been helped by us and we by her. We stop by and skate. She worries less about eating and taking care of things. Life tied the knots, now we undo them. It's a symbiotic relationship. We need each other. The pool is great. The sessions are mellow. We have no need to hurry or stress. There are no uniforms that will be appearing to hassle us and take more from us than they already try and take. Sabrina is pretty cool. She doesn't really seem to understand skating... but she does understand our need. She has hers and we have ours. The two meet. It is a good thing. Thanks to Peanut for doing what was necessary. Thanks Cam and Wong. Thank you to MRZ. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_14122" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Steven Reeves- Monty grind death[/caption]

item.title: thieves
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Joker's Skate Shop was broken into and a ton of things stolen. No good. This ass clown needs to be punished. It is a simple fact. Please watch out for skate stuff at yard sales and flea markets/swap meets. The Reuter family are top shelf, super good people...  This is a small local skate shop and it really angers me that they were disrespected in such a fashion.  Corey Reuter- "We were was broken into last night by 2 kids in a white car. Be on the look out in Huntington Beach area for Someone with a lot of extra skate product and shirts. 714-962-8429. at Jokers Skate Shop." If anyone knows anything, let the police or the Reuter's know. If you help catch this scumbag,  I'll throw in a free BBQ session at Ridiculous for all of your friends! Ozzie

item.title: Daniel Cuervo - Good Luck
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_14136" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Daniel Cuervo in San Jose[/caption] Daniel Cuervo. The Dominican Republic's foremost vertical ruler. The Aerial Action Sports crew saw his unlimited potential and brought him onto the ztuntz team. He competed and ruled in every contest he entered. We are proud to have had him associated with our company. He has moved on to ride for Black Leather Racing. We wish Daniel nothing but continued success and a bright prosperous future. Good luck Daniel. Thank you to MRZ for the image. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Feliz 50 Cumpleanos El Gato
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_14149" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Eddie Elguera- constant progression. Anti Judo[/caption] Happy Fiftieth Birthday Eddie 'El Gato' Elguera. The word went out. There would be a birthday session at the Vans Combi. The social media engine slipped into gear. Travel plans were made. Couches reserved. Phone lines buzzed with anticipation. As the day approached, Ray Zimmerman and I prepared ourselves. We talked about how to present the event and do it justice. We spoke of Eddie's influence. We both grew up in the seventies era of skateboarding. We talked about  the Hester One contests and the changes we saw in the Hester Two series, a year later. We both agreed that Eddie Elguera played a pivotal role in the innovation of technical tricks during that time. We wanted to give this event the respect it deserved. We arrived a bit early  and there was a pretty good sized crew rolling in the Combi and crowded on the decks. Ray set up lights and I started speaking to those I had chosen to question in regards to the man of the moment. "What does Eddie Elguera mean to you and how do you regard his place in skateboarding?" Answers varied. Some pondered. Most readily offered up "Innovator" and more than a few skaters consider Eddie a "Pioneer". The session soon began in earnest. Scott Foss flew with style and calm grace. Adrian Demain, Mike McGill, Jeff Hedges, Owen Neider and others all were ripping. Andy Macdonald was doing something pretty unique. He was riding the Combi pool and was doing a line consisting only of tricks that Eddie invented. It was inspiring to those that actually caught what he was doing. [caption id="attachment_14154" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Andy Macdonald- "For you Eddie. Thanks."[/caption] "If it wasn't for Eddie Elguera, the frontside rock-n-roll wouldn't be a part of skating. Skateboarding would have a hole in it. I learned the frontside rock at thirteen years old, after I saw a photograph of Eddie. The frontside rock is the style, the roots and the ritual of skateboarding. In contests, I always do a frontside rock. If you take away all the cameras, crowds and money, it's just skateboarding. I'd be skating and doing frontside rocks regardless."- Andy Macdonald [caption id="attachment_14156" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Adrian Demain - Judo[/caption] "I started seeing photographs of Eddie in the magazines before I had a concept of how skating was. It was a new world. Eddie was creating a future in skateboarding and this helped me to find my place in the world. I was an awkward kid. It gave me something to strive for. This is where my identity all comes from." - Adrian Demain "He is perfectionism. It is strange that one of my childhood heroes is only two years older than me." - Mike McGill "Eddie Elguera was the innovator. He always came up with completely new stuff."- Lester Kasai [caption id="attachment_14158" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Eric Nash- backside ollie[/caption] "Eddie was innovation. Looking at the magazines, I saw Eddie as one of the first skaters to really mix it up and continually invent things. His intensity during the contests was notable. It really grew intense during the Gold Cups with Duane and Eddie. They had the whole Varibot and Santa Cruz thing going... To me, Eddie Elguera represented change." - Eric Nash [caption id="attachment_14159" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jeff Hedges - Smithvert[/caption] "For me, it all began with Eddie, Stevie and Duane. This is where technical bowl riding really comes from. What they did, makes skateboarding what it is today. Eddie was a huge part of all this." - Jeff Hedges "Eddie Elguera represented that next step. Competitive skating. In the early 1980's he was innovation. He raised the bar high." - Pat Ngoho [caption id="attachment_14161" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Scott Foss - frontside flow[/caption] "It is easier to be the dog than the rabbit. Eddie Elguera was the rabbit. We always chased him as he led the way. He set the standards for that era. Eddie set the bar. It was an honor and a privilege to see him skate. He lifted everyone up." - Scott Foss [caption id="attachment_14160" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Owen Neider[/caption] "I skated Carlsbad in 1976. I saw guys like Wally Inouye. We rode Caster and IPS boards. I rode Del Mar and it was the same. In 1979, Variflex came out. I have to admit that Eddie was the ONLY person to ever get me to change my entire set up due to his skating. I saw him skate and immediately went and bought an Elguera board with crappy Variflex trucks and wheels. He was the only one!" - Owen Neider [caption id="attachment_14163" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian Hosoi - tailgrab[/caption] "Eddie's contribution to skateboarding is iconic. He was the pioneer of technical skating. Guys like Tony Hawk emulated him to progress the sport. What Eddie did was truly special. He liked to take skating to the next level. To see him still progressing is inspiring. He just learned backside Smith grinds. He inspires people in skating, he inspires people to persevere, to stand for something... he is a man of god. I am proud of him. I am proud that he is on Hosoi skateboards and that we get to travel and skate together. We share our love of skateboarding." - Christian Hosoi [caption id="attachment_14165" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Duane, Eddie and Christian[/caption] The microphone was hijacked from the DJ and Eddie spoke about his friendship and rivalry with Duane Peters. Steve Van Doren presented Eddie with a gift and a cake was later brought out and everyone sang Happy Birthday. There were young guns, women and all ages represented and skating in celebration of Eddie Elguera's birthday. It was pretty unreal. Milestones. Memories. [caption id="attachment_14167" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Eddie, Steve Van Doren, Dawn Elguera and Christian[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14166" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Dan Sparagna celebrates his 50th birthday this weekend as well. Rock-n-roll slider into another decade.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14180" align="aligncenter" width="584"] The ladies were well represented.
Lizzie Armanto[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14182" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Restless dreams of youth.
Corey Juneau[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14168" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian carrying the special birthday cake[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14169" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Birthday Boy[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14170" align="aligncenter" width="584"] The Choir[/caption] [caption id="attachment_14171" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Happy Birthday Eddie. We love you brother.[/caption] Thank you to Vans and all the sponsors. Thank you to everyone that celebrated with us. Thank you to all of the skaters that took the time to give me their thoughts and thanks to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie
